revision.text:
{{Other uses of|AAPT}}
The '''American Association of Physics Teachers''' ('''AAPT''') was founded in 1930 for the purpose of "dissemination of knowledge of physics, particularly by way of teaching."<ref>[http://www.aapt.org/aboutaapt/ About AAPT<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> There are more than 10,000 members that reside in over 30 countries. AAPT publications include two [[peer-reviewed journal]]s, the ''[[American Journal of Physics]]'' and ''[[The Physics Teacher]]''. The association has two annual National Meetings (winter and summer) and has regional sections with their own meetings and organization. The association also offers grants and awards for physics educators, including the Richtmyer Memorial Award,<ref>[http://www.aapt.org/Programs/awards/richtmyer.cfm Richtmeyer Memorial Award, AAPT website]</ref> and programs and contests for physics educators and students. It is headquartered at the American Center for Physics in [[College Park, Maryland]].
==History== The American Association of Physics Teachers was founded on December 31, 1930, when forty-five physicists held a meeting during the joint [[American Physical Society|APS]]-AAAS meeting in Cleveland specifically for that purpose.
The AAPT became a founding member of the [[American Institute of Physics]] after the other founding members were convinced of the stability of the AAPT itself after a new constitution for the AAPT was agreed upon.
==Contests== The AAPT sponsors a number of competitions. The [[Physics Bowl]], [[Six Flags]]' [[roller coaster]] contest, and the US Physics Team are just a few. The US physics team is determined by two preliminary exams and a week and a half long "boot camp." Each year, five members are selected to compete against dozens of countries in the [[International Physics Olympiad]] (IPHO).
== See also == * [[The Physics Teacher]] * [[Oersted Medal]] * [[American Institute of Physics]] * [[American Journal of Physics]] * [[Physics Outreach]]
==References== <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.aapt.org/ American Association of Physics Teachers web page] * [http://www.aapt.org/Events/ AAPT sponsored events] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100731075150/http://library.uncg.edu/depts/archives/mss/html/Mss067.htm Finding Aid for the American Association of Physics Teachers, South Atlantic Coast Section Records] at the [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Physics education]] [[Category:Physics organizations]] [[Category:Professional associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Academic organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1930]] [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Teacher associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Education-related professional associations]] [[Category:American Association of Physics Teachers]] [[Category:1930 establishments in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Democracy}} '''Anticipatory democracy''' is a theory of [[civics]] relying on democratic [[decision making]] that takes into account [[futurology|predictions of future events]] that have some credibility with the electorate. The phrase was coined by [[Alvin Toffler]] in his book ''[[Future Shock]]''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=qsPgTpt_jrKEB5CI0IAF&ct=result&id=SvbQAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22Anticipatory+democracy%22&q=Toffler#search_anchor | title=Anticipatory democracy | work=The Indian journal of public administration, Volume 26 | date=1980 | accessdate=December 8, 2011 | pages=879}}</ref> and was expanded on in the 1978 book ''Anticipatory Democracy'', edited by [[Clement Bezold]].
Other well-known advocates of the anticipatory approach include [[Newt Gingrich]], [[Heidi Toffler]], [[K. Eric Drexler]], and [[Robin Hanson]]. They all advocate approaches where the public, not just experts, participate in this "anticipation".
The FutureMAP program of the [[Information Awareness Office]] program of the [[United States of America|United States]] government proposed a prediction market prior to its cancellation on July 29, 2003.
== Variants ==
[[Bioregional democracy]] can appear as a variant of anticipatory democracy in that it anticipates (using a similar scientific process) the [[ecological health]] outcomes of any given action. However it usually relies more on far less fragile means, and less on compared measures and quantities.
An alternative, [[deliberative democracy]], may combine with either the anticipatory or the bioregional model. It relies less on formal models and a [[market system]] for betting on future events, and more on discussion.
Deliberative, anticipatory and bioregional approaches can all be considered variants of [[participatory democracy]] with different thresholds of ease of participation, [[Legal burden of proof|burden of proof]], concern for non-human life or future generations, and reflection of participants' tolerances versus preferences or ideals of [[truth]]. Sometimes a deliberative model is described as more [[left-wing politics|"left"]] and an anticipatory model as more [[right-wing politics|"right"]]. Those who wish to avoid this debate and see merits to both approaches, e.g. [[Green politics|Greens]], usually prefer the generic term "[[participatory democracy]]". This term has become fundamental to [[green politics]] itself.
Other terms which likewise have more specific associations with advocates or methods include: [[grassroots democracy]], [[semi-direct democracy]], [[consensus democracy]].
==See also== *[[Democracy (varieties)]] *[[List of politics-related topics]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *[[Future Shock]] - Alvin Toffler *''Anticipatory Democracy: People in the Politics of the Future'', Clement Bezold, Random House, 1978. {{ISBN|0-394-41236-2}}. [[Category:Active citizenship]] [[Category:Participatory democracy]] [[Category:Types of democracy]]

revision.text:
The '''Arts Olympiad''' is an international art competition for children ages 8 to 12 organized by [[International Child Art Foundation]] with one million participants from seventy countries. Each competition is four years long and it is held every four year. The competition includes the element of art and peace to encourage children around the world to use creativity and cooperation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Promising Practices - Arts Olympiad|url=http://www.arizonahealthmatters.org/modules.php?op=modload&name=PromisePractice&file=promisePractice&pid=769|publisher=The Healthy Communities Institute|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==History== Dr. Ashfaq Ishaq, founder of the International Child Art Foundation, started the first Arts Olympiad competition in 1999<ref name="1st-ao">{{cite web|title=1st Arts Olympiad (1997-2000)|url=http://www.icaf.org/whatwedo/ao/1st-ao.php|publisher=International Child Art Foundation|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref> to address the issue which was coined decades earlier as the "fourth grade slump" in creativity.<ref>{{cite book|last=Torrance|first=Ellis Paul|title=Understanding the fourth grade slump in creative thinking: final report|year=1967|publisher=University of Minnesota|pages=316}}</ref> The researchers at the time suggested that the phenomenon is a result of a drop in creativity around the ages of nine as they start conforming to [[standardized test]]ing and to please parents and teachers. The plan was to let children who were the winners of [[U.S. state]]s and other countries to come together in a festival to let them work together and learn other cultures with the goal to move future generations toward [[World peace|global peace]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Jane Hess|title=Get Out and Give Back: World Children’s Festival|url=http://www.washingtonlife.com/2011/06/13/get-out-and-give-back-world-children%E2%80%99s-festival/|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Washington Life Magazine|date=13 June 2011}}</ref>
The theme for the first Art Olympiad was ''My World in the Year 2000'' to ask children to create art in which they envisioned themselves in the [[new millennium]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Future Of Peace: Art By Young People|url=http://go.worldbank.org/HE9OOAUR30|publisher=The World Bank Group|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref> There was one million children in 86 countries in the program which was run between 1997 and 2000. The winning pieced from around the world were exhibited at the ''World Children’s Festival'' in 1999 on the [[National Mall]] in [[Washington, DC]]. The artworks were also later exhibited at the [[White House Millennium Council#White House Millennium Celebration|White House Millennium Celebration]], the [[United Nations Headquarters]], and the 2003 [[Annual Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group|World Bank/IMF Annual Meetings]] in [[Dubai]].<ref name="1st-ao"/>
Since then the format of the global competition, a festival in Washington, DC and global exhibitions have been following in the next Arts Olympiad cycles. The 2nd Arts Olympiad was held between 2001 and 2004 with the theme of ''Me in the New Millennium''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dally|first=Ashley|title=Me in the New Millennium.(Perspective)(ICAF's 2000-2004 Arts Olympiad)|journal=ChildArt|date=1 April 2003|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-140305540.html|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref> Starting in the 3rd Arts Olympiad (2005-2008), the theme was shifted to relate art and sport<ref>{{cite web|title=Culture of Peace Project and Resources: Arts Olympiad|url=http://www3.unesco.org/iycp/uk/uk_visu_projet.asp?Proj=00087|publisher=International Year for the Culture of Peace - Unesco|accessdate=8 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707045049/http://www3.unesco.org/iycp/uk/uk_visu_projet.asp?Proj=00087#|archive-date=2010-07-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> to promote the artist-athlete ideal.<ref>{{cite web|title=The President's Challenge / About / Advocates / Nonprofit|url=https://www.presidentschallenge.org/about/advocates/nonprofit.shtml|publisher=The President’s Council on Fitness, Sports & Nutrition|accessdate=8 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025013502/https://www.presidentschallenge.org/about/advocates/nonprofit.shtml#|archive-date=2012-10-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The fourth Arts Olympiad (2009-2012) continued the same theme with title ''My Favorite Sport''.<ref>{{cite web|title=NCAC Partners International Child Art Foundation(ICAF) |url=http://www.ncac.gov.ng/ncacicf.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130222172708/http://www.ncac.gov.ng/ncacicf.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 February 2013 |publisher=National Council for Arts & Culture, Nigeria |accessdate=8 January 2013 }}</ref>
==Selection Process== During the first two years of the competition, local schools are participated in the Arts Olympiad lesson plan. The artworks as the result of the lessons are then put into a selection process.
The selection process in the United States is first done from at the local [[school district]]. The selection of artworks from within a school or school district. The artworks are then submitted to Washington, DC for another selection to have a representative of each participating state.<ref>{{cite news|title=Berwick Academy selected to represent Maine at World Children's Festival|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110311/GJNEWS_01/703119949&template=SouthernMaineRegion|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Fosters Daily Democrat|date=11 March 2011}}</ref>
In other countries, the partner in each country will administrate the selection. The selection can be in many phases involving the competition at the local level and at the national level.<ref>{{cite news|title=150 in Arts Olympiad|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/1/3/central/13010258&sec=central|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=The Star Online|date=3 January 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gana niño mazatleco Olimpiada del Arte a nivel nacional|url=http://www.noroeste.com.mx/publicaciones.php?id=660595&id_seccion=84363|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Noroeste.com|date=10 February 2011}}</ref>
The winners who represent the participating U.S. states and countries are invited to the World Children's Festival in Washington, DC.
==World Children's Festival== The World Children's Festival is a three-day festival held every four years on the National Mall in Washington, DC for winners of the Arts Olympiad to participate. The festival includes over 50 performances and many art-related workshops. It also has sessions for the winners from different countries to co-create artworks with many adult artists.<ref name="south-south">{{cite news|last=Jordan |first=Richard |title=4th World Children's Festival Held at the National Mall in Washington, DC |url=http://www.southsouthnews.com/pages/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=c45230b5-620e-4126-9bfe-9bcfca02812b |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714104844/http://www.southsouthnews.com/pages/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=c45230b5-620e-4126-9bfe-9bcfca02812b |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2013 |newspaper=South-South News |date=22 June 2011 }}</ref>
Before the event, the Arts Olympiad winners from Washington, D.C. are asked to be ambassadors for the festival and exchange emails with international winners to welcome to the festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=The World Children's Festival|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/gog/misc-events/the-world-childrens-festival,1209274/critic-review.html|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=30 December 2012}}</ref> The international winners are welcomed to the host families around the Washington area.
Children share ideas and work together during the three-day festival. On the last night of the festival, the celebratory dinner is held with all guests dressing in [[Folk costume|national attire]].<ref name="south-south"/>
Similar festivals have been replicated in other counties such as the European Children’s Festival at Olympia Park in Munich in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|title=Founder of World’s Largest Art Program for Children Earns The Academy’s Distinguished Service Award|url=http://ussa.edu/publications/news/2011/10/27/founder-of-worlds-largest-art-program-for-children-earns-the-academys-distinguished-service-award/|publisher=United States Sports Academy|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==International Exhibitions== After the World Children's Festival, the winning pieces will travel to exhibitions in the U.S. and internationally. The past exhibitions have been in [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Germany]], [[Israel]], [[South Korea]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Japan]], [[Uganda]], [[Italy]], [[Egypt]], [[Switzerland]], [[United Kingdom]], and [[Qatar]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ICAF Exhibitions 1998-2011|url=http://icaf.org/pdfs/ICAF%20Exhibitions%201998-2011.pdf|publisher=International Child Art Foundation|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==Roles of Winners== The organizer have seen the potential and the importance of Art Olympiad winners to promote the cause. An example was demonstrated when a winner from [[Peru]] who have gone through difficulties in arranging competition because there was no office of the Internal Child Art Foundation in the country, that child eventually set up and organize the competition in the country for the next season with the support from the [[Ministry of Education (Peru)|ministry of education]]. With that, they started encouraging the winners to contribute back to the program and set up a youth board for the organization.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ashfaq Ishaq Discusses Challenges Faced Due To Lack of Arts Education |url=http://www.eclips.cornell.edu/clip.do?id=5127&clipID=5127&tab=TabClipPage |publisher=Charles H. Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management, Cornell University |accessdate=8 January 2013 |date=12 May 2004 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Youth Board Members=== In each cycle of the Arts Olympiad competition, a number of winners are choose to serve the youth board of the organization. Their roles are to be organization's [[spokesperson]]s, conduct fundraising to support the programs, write for ChildArt magazine, help stage and be the [[master of ceremonies]] at the World Children's Festival, and nominate innovative leaders, companies and organizations for the World Children's Award.
Since the formation of the youth board there have been 38 members from two dozen counties.<ref>{{cite web|title=The ICAF Youth Board|url=http://www.icaf.org/about/youth.php|publisher=International Child Art Foundation|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://icaf.org/artsolympiad/ Official website]
[[Category:Youth culture]] [[Category:Peace education]] [[Category:Youth events]] [[Category:Art competitions]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1999]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Bernard Daly Educational Fund | image = Bernard Daly and Oregon map with Lake County highlighted.jpg | image_size = 300 | caption = Dr. Daly with map of Lake County, Oregon | type = Private trust fund | founded_date = 1922 | founder = [[Bernard Daly]] | location = [[Lakeview, Oregon|Lakeview]], [[Oregon]], [[United States|USA]] | key_people = Dr. Mike Sabin (chairman) | area_served = [[Lake County, Oregon|Lake County]], Oregon | focus = Education | method = College scholarships | revenue = | num_employees = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = }}
The '''Bernard Daly Educational Fund''' is an education [[trust fund]] established in 1922 for the benefit of students graduating from high school in [[Lake County, Oregon]]. It is the oldest continuously operated place-based college scholarship fund in the [[United States]]. The fund is managed by a local [[board of trustees]]. Its assets total over $6,800,000, making it one of the largest scholarship funds in [[Oregon]].
== Bernard Daly ==
[[Bernard Daly]] was a doctor, businessman, banker, rancher, state representative, state senator, county judge, and regent of Oregon State Agricultural College (now [[Oregon State University]]). Daly was born in [[Ireland]] on February 17, 1858. He immigrated to the [[United States]] with his parents in 1864. After graduating from medical school, he joined the [[United States Army]]. In 1887, Daly left the army and moved to [[Lakeview, Oregon]] where he began a private medical practice. Over the years, Daly played a very important role in the economic development of Lake County, establishing a number of successful businesses.<ref name="FEC">Cooper, Forest E., ''Introducing Dr. Daly'', Lake County Historical Society, Maverick Publications: Bend, Oregon, 1986</ref><ref>LaLande, Jeff and Cain Allen, [http://www.ohs.org/education/oregonhistory/historical_records/dspDocument.cfm?doc_ID=F2976147-B540-BAE5-46F263903C3840DD "Dr. Bernard Daly"], The Oregon History Project, [[Oregon Historical Society]], ''www.ohs.org'', 2005.</ref>
When Daly died on January 4, 1920, he had business interests throughout Lake County. He was the largest stockholder in the Bank of Lakeview. He owned the largest ranch in south-central Oregon as well as a number of other businesses. He also owned at least 14 buildings in downtown Lakeview. All together his partnerships and investments brought the value of his estate to almost $1,000,000, a very large sum in 1920.<ref name="LCE">[http://www.irishsheepherders.com/dr_bernard_daly.htm "Dr. Bernard Daly Dies"], ''Lake County Examiner'' and ''Lakeview Herald'', Lakeview, Oregon, January 8, 1920 (posted on Irish Sheepherders of Lake County website, ''www.irishsheepherders.com'').</ref>
== Scholarship fund ==
In his will, Daly gave his fortune to the people of Lake County in the form of the Bernard Daly Educational Fund. In his will, Daly wrote:
{{cquote|It is my earnest desire to help, aid and assist worthy and ambitious young men and women of my beloved county of Lake, to acquire a good education, so that they may be better fitted and qualified to appreciate and help to preserve the laws and constitution of this free country, defend its flag, and by their conduct as good citizens reflect honor on Lake county and the state of Oregon.<ref name="FEC"/>}}
The fact that his will specifically directed that Daly scholarships be granted to women as well as men was very progressive for that era. Based on the terms of the will, the scholarships must be used to attend "schools, colleges, and technical schools of the State of Oregon."<ref name="FEC"/>
The first Daly Fund scholarships were awarded in 1922.<ref name="FEC"/> Today, the education fund Daly established is the oldest continuously operating place-based college scholarship in the United States.<ref>Stern, Sam, [http://blogs.oregonstate.edu/lakeview/about-this-blog Daly Fund Research Project], College of Education, Oregon State University, Corvallis, Oregon, accessed 14 October 2018.</ref> It provides scholarships to three Lake County high schools, located in Lakeview, [[Paisley, Oregon|Paisley]], and [[Silver Lake, Oregon|Silver Lake]]. Together, the three schools graduate approximately 100 students per year.<ref>[http://www.publicschoolreview.com/county_schools/stateid/OR/county/41037 "Lake County High Schools – Oregon"], Public School Review, ''www.publicschoolreview.com'', January 10, 2009.</ref> Each year, approximately 40 Lake County students attend college on Daly scholarships. The scholarship provides $2,000 per term, up to a maximum of $8,200 per year.<ref name="IRS">[http://204.203.220.33/EINS/936025466/936025466_2006_03666512.PDF "Return of Private Foundation"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, IRS Form 990-PF, Internal Revenue Service, United States Department of Treasury, Washington, D.C, May 31, 2007.</ref> Since the fund was established, over 2,000 students from Lake County communities have attended college on Daly Fund scholarships.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080528204618/http://gsmith.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=PressReleases.Detail&PressRelease_id=deea71aa-13a2-42fe-a28c-40daacdad502&Month=5&Year=2008 "Smith, Wyden Introduce Bill to Rename Lakeview Post Office After Local Hero"], Press release, Press Office of Senator [[Gordon Smith (politician)|Gordon Smith]], United States Senate, Washington, D.C., May 16, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2008_record&page=S4183&position=all "Statements on Introduced Bill and Joint Resolutions"], S. 3015, by Senator Gordon Smith and Senator Ron Wyden, ''Congressional Record—Senate'', Washington, D.C., May 14, 2008, p. S4183.</ref>
== Fund administration ==
Since it was established in 1922, the Fund has continued to grow. As of 2006, it had over $6,800,000 in assets available to support scholarships for Lake County students.<ref name="IRS"/>
The Bernard Daly Educational Fund is governed by a five-person board of trustees. As of 2007, the trustees are: Dr. Mike Sabin of Lakeview (chairman); James C. Lynch of Lakeview (secretary/treasurer); Alan Parks of Silver Lake (trustee); and Ann Tracy of Lakeview (trustee).<ref name="IRS"/>
==See also== * [[Lakeview High School (Oregon)|Lakeview High School]] * [[North Lake School District (Oregon)|North Lake School District]] * [[Paisley School District]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Education in Lake County, Oregon]] [[Category:Education in Oregon]] [[Category:Scholarships in the United States]] [[Category:1922 establishments in Oregon]]
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=71wrEPvlhyU&feature=youtu.be Daly Fund Research Project video]

revision.comment: /* Bishop Scott Grammar and Divinity School */ Convert first= to author1= and so on to clear error. This article was on the WikiProject: Oregon Clean-up list ---> CS1: Missing author or editor.
revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name = Bishop Scott Academy |native_name = |latin_name = |image = Bishop Scott Academy, 1895.png |image_size = 250px |caption = Second building, as depicted on 1 January 1895 |motto = |established = 1870 |type = Defunct as of 1904 |city =[[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] |state =[[Oregon]] |country =[[United States|USA]] |campus = |free_label = |free = |colors = |colours = |mascot = |nickname = |affiliations = |footnotes = |address = |telephone = |coor = |logo = }} '''Bishop Scott Academy''' was a school located in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] in the U.S. state of [[Oregon]]. Affiliated with the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]], the school was named for the [[Bishop]] [[Thomas F. Scott (bishop)|Thomas Fielding Scott]]. The school opened in 1870 to educate young men in good citizenship and prepare them to enter the ministry. Later a military department was added to the school before the academy closed in 1904. The school organized the first [[American football]] team and held the first football game in the [[Pacific Northwest]] in 1889.
==Prior schools==
=== Trinity School for Boys === The academy was related to an earlier attempt by Scott to found a diocesan school.<ref name=hma/> The Reverend William Richmond had started a school at [[Yamhill, Oregon|Yamhill]] in 1852.<ref>Robson says that Richmond's school started at Yamhill, was moved to [[Milwaukie, Oregon|Milwaukie]], then to Lake Oswego.</ref> Bishop Scott moved Richmond's school to present-day [[Lake Oswego, Oregon]], where Scott had purchased 70 acres that included a school building dating to 1850. Here Scott established the Diocesan School for Boys.<ref name=Marschner /> Bernard Cornelius, a graduate of [[Trinity College, Dublin]], was appointed in 1856 by Scott as principal over 17 boarders. A primary department opened in 1858, and the school was renamed Trinity School for Boys. The school offered "both religious and secular education".<ref name=Marschner /><ref name=Tyler>{{cite journal|last=Tyler|first=Robert L|title=Thomas Fielding Scott: Bishop of Oregon|journal=Oregon Historical Quarterly|date=March 1954|volume=1|issue=55}}</ref> Cornelius resigned in 1860, and the school closed for two years. In 1862 it reopened under leadership of the Reverend Michael Fackler. Although Cornelius returned to the reigns in 1863, he could not halt declining enrollment. Trinity school closed in 1866<ref>Tyler says the school closed in 1865.</ref> and the trustees sold the property.<ref name=Marschner>{{cite book|last=Marschner|first=Janice|title=Oregon 1859: A Snapshot in Time|year=2008|publisher=Timber Press|location=Portland|isbn=978-0881928730|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-UW6M_gw48C&pg=PA68&dq=Trinity+School+for+Boys%2BOregon#v=onepage&q=Trinity%20School%20for%20Boys%2BOregon&f=false}}</ref><ref name="Oregon">Corning, Howard M. 1956. ''Dictionary of Oregon History''. Binfords & Mort Publishing.</ref>
Funds and property were provided to Scott's successor, [[Benjamin Wistar Morris (bishop)|Bishop B. Wistar Morris]], to establish another school, but located in [[Portland, Oregon]]. The land comprised 38 city lots along 19th Street,<ref name=Matson>{{cite journal|last=Matson|first=Robert W|title=Joseph Wood Hill: "Civilian Soldier" in Education and Politics|journal=Oregon Historical Quarterly|date=Spring 1989|volume=90|issue=1|pages=5–38}}</ref> between Couch and Everett Streets in Portland. The donors were Captain George H. Flanders and his sister, Mrs. Caroline Couch (wife of [[John H. Couch]]).<ref name="scott">{{cite book|last=Scott|first=Harvey Whitefield|title=History of Portland, Oregon: with illustrations and biographical sketches of prominent citizens and pioneers|year=1890|publisher=D. Mason & Company|location=Syracuse, NY}}</ref> Morris laid the cornerstone on July 5, 1870.<ref name=Oregonian>{{cite news|title=Oregon's Schools|url=http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1900-01-01/ed-1/seq-24/|accessdate=7 February 2013|newspaper=The Morning Oregonian|date=January 1, 1900|page=24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Laying a Corner Stone|newspaper=The Morning Oregonian|date=July 7, 1870|page=2}}</ref>
=== Bishop Scott Grammar and Divinity School === [[File:Bishop Scott Grammar and Divinity School.png|thumbnail|right|The Bishop Scott Grammar School in 1874]] The newly completed Bishop Scott Grammar and Divinity School opened as a boarding and day-school for boys on September 6, 1870, under principal Charles H. Allen.<ref name="Oregon" /><ref name="scott" /> Comprising three storeys above a basement, the building housed 2 classrooms, recitation rooms, a parlour, library, 16 rooms for boarders, a suite for the principal and his family, and its own chapel, called Saint Timothy's. Although the total costs amounted to $15,000, no debt remained.<ref name=Matson /><ref name=Journal>{{cite book|title=Journal of the Proceedings of the 11th Annual Convention and the 46th Annual Report of the Church in the Diocese of Oregon|year=1899|publisher=E F Palmer|location=Portland, OR}}</ref>
A year after opening the school had a new head master: Professor R. W. Laing, M.A., L.L.D., assisted by the Reverend George Burton.<ref>{{cite book|last=Farrington|first=William G|title=Church almanac for the year of our Lord, 1872|year=1871|publisher=Protestant Episcopal Tract Society|location=New York}}</ref>
By 1873 the property was valued at $30,000, after the addition of the chapel, school rooms, and the dormitory. Costs were defrayed from tuition fees of $150 per annum, and interest from an $7,000 endowment—the proceeds from the sale of the Oswego property. Eighty pupils attended school, thirteen down from the previous year, drawn from Oregon, Washington, California, Utah, Alaska, and British Columbia. The faculty comprised three teachers: Junior Master, William M. Barker; Primary Master, Mr. Grant; and Senior Master, Rev. A. N. Wrixon.<ref name=Report /> As chaplain, Burton conducted services "in the large schoolroom of the Grammar School" at 10.30am, and Sunday School at 2pm in August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Home News|url=http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn84022673/1873-08-08/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=12 February 2013|newspaper=The New Northwest|date=8 August 1873|location=Portland, OR}}</ref>
At the start of Christmas Term on 1 September, Rev. Burton, now rector of Trinity Parish, was ensconced as head master.<ref>{{cite book|last=Shinn|first=George Wolfe|title=King's handbook of notable Episcopal churches in the United States|year=1889|publisher=Moses King|location=Boston, MA|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XM8YAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> As it had been since 1870, the school was still administered directly by Bishop Morris. Subjects included modern languages, music, singing, drawing, chemistry, and penmanship. Oregon's superintendent of education found that the grammar school's "philosophical and chemical apparatus [were] unsurpassed in the State", and mentioned that the school library contained 1,500 books.<ref name=Report />
The school had replaced almost all its faculty by 1874, and added women to the staff for the first time. Laing and Barker continued, alongside the new head master and chaplain, Rev. D'Estaing Jennings, M.A. Miss I. A. Buss was added as "Preceptress" (female teacher), and Matron Maria Emery had been appointed. A military tone was introduced, in the form of Drill Master R. R. Anderson and the organization of the Bishop Scott Cadets. Drilling was viewed not only in terms of military preparedness, but as a form of exercise.<ref>{{cite news|title=Education in Oregon: St Helen's Hall and the Bishop Scott Grammar School|url=http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn85042522/1874-03-21/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=12 February 2013|newspaper=Willamette Farmer|date=21 March 1874|page=3}}</ref><ref>Other newly appointed faculty included drawing teacher Edward T. Coleman and music teacher Richard T. Yarndley.</ref>
On 8 November 1877 the grammar school was heavily damaged by fire.<ref name="Oregon" /><ref name=Report>{{cite book|title=Report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction|year=1874|publisher=Mart. V. Brown, State Printer|location=Salem, OR|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WqlYv_f8QlYC|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> Before fire almost destroyed the library and equipment, the enrollment stood at 43 day pupils and 40 boarders.<ref name=Biennial>{{cite book|title=Biennial Report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Oregon to the Legislative Assembly. 10th Regular Session|year=1878|volume=3|publisher=Mart. V. Brown, State Printer|location=Salem, OR|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D200AQAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> [[File:Joseph Wood Hill, ca. 1905..png|150px|thumbnail|Joseph Wood Hill (b. 1856), in ca. 1905.]] Joseph Wood Hill was the new principal when the rebuilt school opened on the same premises in September 1878.<ref name="Oregon" /><ref name="Oregonian" /> Burton had been deposed by Bishop Morris in May that year.<ref>{{cite book|title=Journal of the Eleventh Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church|year=1878|publisher=Orphan's Press|location=Brooklyn, NY|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xBsRAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA104&dq|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> The new building was smaller than the one it replaced, although "admirable" and "of superior architectural character", to fit in with the homes in the surrounding area.<ref name=Matson /><ref name=Biennial />
Hill was a native of [[Westport, Connecticut|Westport]], [[Connecticut]], having attained a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] from [[Yale University]] earlier in 1878. He had responded to an address that Bishop Scott gave to a class at Yale. [[Noah Porter]], Yale's president, recommended Hill for his character, teaching experience, and maturity.<ref name=Biennial /> After his appointment, Hill studied medicine at [[Willamette University College of Medicine|Willamette University's College of Medicine]] in Portland,<ref name=Matson /> graduating as a [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] in 1881. At college he rowed, and became a member of the [[Gamma Nu]] fraternity.<ref name=Gaston>{{cite book|last=Gaston|first=Joseph|title=Portland, Oregon, Its History and Builders: In Connection with the Antecedent Explorations, Discoveries, and Movements of the Pioneers that Selected the Site for the Great City of the Pacific, Volume 3|year=1911|publisher=S.J. Clarke Publishing Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v0gOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA452&dq=%22Bishop+Scott+Academy%22#v=onepage&q=%22Bishop%20Scott%20Academy%22&f=false|pages=451–52}}</ref>
Only five boarding pupils attended the school at the start, and there were "less than twenty pupils, all told".<ref name=Journal /> Hill leased the school building from the bishop, and later from the board of [[trustees]] that had been appointed when Oregon became a separate [[diocese]] in 1889.<ref name=Journal />
Echoing the beliefs of Bishop Scott in the value of private over public education,<ref name=Tyler /> Hill modelled the school after the private boarding schools on the east coast, like the one that he himself had attended. He filled the initial faculty vacancies with Yale graduates, such as John W. Gavin and English teacher Allan Elsworth. At the same time he did subsidize from his own pocket those students for whom the $300 annual fees were a hardship.<ref name=Matson />
Hill spent his vacations visiting exemplary private schools throughout the United States, and gradually became convinced that military discipline was essential for the Academy. In 1886, he declared that pupils should wear uniforms.<ref name=Matson />
Illustrating the amount of control the principal was granted by Bishop Morris, Hill renamed the school the Bishop Scott Academy in 1887. A military department was added, and the Academy became the first school on the West Coast to adopt military discipline. Hill had an [[Armory (military)|armory]] built that measured 5,000 square feet—"the largest indoor space in Portland" for some time. Although intended as a drill hall, the armory was also used for dances, which Hill believed would provide cadets with a graceful posture.<ref name=Matson /><ref name=Oregonian /> [[File:Bishop Scott Academy advertisement 1900.png|thumbnail|right|A 1900 newspaper advertisement for the Academy]] In order to promote military training, the federal government loaned weapons to schools which employed a qualified officer as military commandant.<ref name=Matson /> Hill appointed Lieutenant Colonel F. E. Patterson in 1887 as instructor in mathematics and [[military tactics]]. Consequently, the steamship ''Oregon'' brought [[Springfield rifle]]s and "two 3-inch rifled field pieces and carriages" in 1890 to the Academy "from the [[Benicia Arsenal|Benicia arsenal]], California". Academy cadets could now learn how to use [[light artillery]].<ref>{{cite news|title=City and County Official Paper|url=http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn96061150/1890-07-02/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=The Daily Morning Astorian|date=2 July 1890|pages=3}}</ref>
In 1891 the Academy became the first school permitted to sit Yale University's entrance examinations without direct supervision of Yale faculty.<ref name=Matson /> The uniforms for the intake of 234 students that year were supplied by Thomas Kay Woolen Mills' store in Salem.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn99063952/1891-09-24/ed-1/seq-3/|title=Uniforms|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Evening Capital Journal|date=September 24, 1891}}</ref>
Gavin organized the first [[American football|football]] team in the Northwest at the Academy, which held the first football game in the Northwest in 1889. Gavin had learned to play while studying at Yale. Until that time, [[rugby union]] had been the preferred form of football at the school.<ref name=hma>{{cite web|last=Robson|first=Mary Farrand|title=Hill Military Academy|url=http://gesswhoto.com/hill-academy.html|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Kristyn McIvor|author2=Joel D. Freeman|author3=Luana Hellmann Hill|title=Legacy of the twenty-six: a celebration of the first 100 years of the Multnomah Athletic Club|year=1991|publisher=Multnomah Athletic Club|location=[Portland, Or.]|isbn=978-0-9629107-0-8|edition=1st}}</ref>
Like many institutions across the [[United States]], the school was badly affected by the economic depression that followed the [[Panic of 1893]]. Hill recalled that he had 70 pupils by June 1893; but in September only 12 returned when the school re-opened.<ref name=Journal /> The principal's own financial state also suffered due to the Panic, his investment in real estate, and the general contraction of the Oregon economy. Hill tried to deflect the impact by assigning the lease of the school to the diocesan secretary, thus placing the Academy out of the reach of his debtors. He also transferred some of his properties to his wife.<ref name=Matson />
Desiring to further formalize the military aspect of the Academy, Hill asked for a serving officer to be assigned. Accordingly, the federal War Department appointed Captain W. A. Kimball in 1895.<ref name=Matson /> The [[United States Army]] now in effect controlled the Academy's military section.<ref name="Oregon" /> When the [[Spanish–American War]] broke out, 30 alumni from the Academy served, fourteen as [[Officer (armed forces)#Commissioned officers|commissioned officers]].<ref name=Matson />
The school also became the first in the Pacific Northwest to implement the [[Sloyd]] system of instruction, with Hill personally contributing financially to the purchasing in 1895 of the required equipment.<ref name=Matson /> [[File:BSA 1904.png|thumb|1903 advertisement for Bishop Scott Academy]] After 23 years of service, Hill retired in 1901 after a disagreement with the school's board of trustees. Some of the trustees had argued that the diocese should operate the school. They said that the diocese had acted outside its legal limits in granting a lease to Hill.<ref name=Matson /> Not wishing to become an employee of the diocese, Hill departed on amiable terms. His first wife, Jessie K. Adams, died in 1901. Hill married Laura E. MacEwan, the widow of the Academy's chaplain, that same year. Originally a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], Hill shifted allegiance to the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican party]] in 1896, due to his support for the [[gold standard]]. A [[Freemason]], Hill obtained the [[Knights Templar (Freemasonry)|Knights Templar]] degree of the [[York Rite]].<ref name=Gaston /> He started the [[Hill Military Academy]] elsewhere in the city, and later became an agent for [[William Howard Taft|President William Howard Taft]].<ref name=Matson /><ref>{{cite web|title=Young Cadets Drill at Hill Military Academy|url=http://www.ohs.org/education/oregonhistory/historical_records/dspDocument.cfm?doc_ID=00080420-24AB-1E9F-9D1880B05272FE9F|publisher=Oregon History Project|accessdate=September 24, 2007}}</ref>
Arthur C. Newill, who had read [[classics]] at [[Balliol College]], [[Oxford]], was appointed as Hill's successor. The Academy's enrollment declined after having reached 234 in 1901, and under financial pressure the Diocese closed the school in 1904.<ref name="Oregon" />
Subsequently, several unsuccessful attempts were made to revive the Academy in [[Yamhill County, Oregon]].<ref name="Oregon" /> For example, in June 1913 ''The Ontario Argus'' announced that "the Bishop Scott Grammar School for Boys" would reopen in September, north of Yamhill.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brief news of Oregon|url=http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn00063520/1913-06-19/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=12 February 2013|newspaper=The Ontario Argus|date=19 June 1913}}</ref>
== Faculty, 1870-1904 == {{colbegin}} * Right Rev. B. Wistar Morris, D.D. - Rector, 1870-1904 * Dr. J. W. Hill, B.A., M.D. - Principal, Mathematics and English, 1878-1901 * Samuel W. Scott, B.A. (Yale) - Head Master, 1888, 1889, 1890;<ref name=Ninth>{{cite book|title=Ninth Biennial Report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Oregon Presented to the Legislative Assembly, Regular Session, 1891|year=1891|publisher=Frank C. Ellsworth, B.A. (Yale), 1886, 1890,<ref name=Ninth/><ref name=Seventh/> 1894, Latin, Science;<ref name=Eleventh/> vice-principal, 1892,<ref name=Tenth>{{cite book|title=Tenth Biennial Report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Oregon Presented to the Legislative Assembly, Regular Session, 1893|year=1893|publisher=Frank C. Baker, State Printer|location=Salem, OR|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o0QTAAAAIAAJ&dq|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> 1894<ref name=Eleventh>{{cite book|title=Eleventh Biennial Report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Oregon Presented to the Legislative Assembly, Regular Session|year=1895|publisher=Frank C. Baker, State Printer|location=Salem, OR|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o0QTAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> * Harold B. Fiske, B. S. (Yale) - Mathematics, Science, History, 1886<ref name=Seventh/> * Nielson Hagerup (Christiana Art School, Norway) (b. 1864-d.1922) - artist, Drawing and Painting, 1886, 1888,<ref name=Eighth/> 1890,<ref name=Ninth/> 1892<ref name=Tenth/> * Sara D. F. Thayer (Rochester), Commercial Department and Pemanship, 1886, 1888, 1890, 1892, 1894<ref name=Ninth/><ref name=Eighth/><ref name=Tenth/><ref name=Eleventh/> * E. Thibeau, Modern Languages, 1886, 1890<ref name=Ninth/> * James White, B.A. (Toronto), 1886, 1888, 1890,<ref name=Ninth/><ref name=Eighth/> 1892<ref name=Tenth/> * Miss Katherine Wilson - Dancing, Deportment, 1892,<ref name=Tenth/> 1894<ref name=Eleventh/> {{colend}} Note: Incomplete list; dates refer to when individuals are mentioned in biennial reports of the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Oregon.
== Alumni == {{colbegin}} *[[Franklin F. Korell]] (1889-1965), politician *[[Clifton N. McArthur]] (1879-1923), politician *[[Benjamin Wistar Morris, III]] (1870–1944), architect *Adolph D. Schmidt (1886-1947), brewer, hotelier *[[Loyal B. Stearns]] (1853-1936), politician *[[Walter L. Tooze]] (1887-1956), politician *Frederick Eugene Trotter (1873-1939), physician<ref>[http://www.hml.org/mmhc/mdindex/trotter.html Frederick Eugene Trotter.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111062646/http://www.hml.org/mmhc/mdindex/trotter.html |date=November 11, 2007 }} Hawaii Medical Library, accessed September 24, 2007.</ref> *[[Cal Young]] (1871-1959), first head coach of the [[Oregon Ducks football]] team, student from ca. 1886-1891 and teacher (2 yrs., incl. 1892<ref name=Tenth/>) at the school<ref>{{cite book|author=Frederica Coons|title=The Early History of Eugene|publisher=Find A Grave (reprinted)|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/6563668}}</ref> {{colend}}

revision.text:
'''CS50''' ('''Computer Science 50''') is an on-campus and online introductory course on [[computer science]] from [[Harvard]] and, as of 2015, [[Yale]] Universities. And, as of 2016, available in high schools as an [[AP Computer Science|AP]] course. The course material is available for free with a range of certificates available for a fee. The on-campus version is Harvard's largest class with 800 students, 102 staff and up to 2,200 participants in their regular [[hackathon]]s.<ref name=Pappano>{{cite web|last=Pappano|first=Laura|title=10 Courses With a Twist|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/13/education/edlife/10-courses-with-a-twist.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref><ref name=Farrell>{{cite web|last=Farrell|first=Michael|title=Computer science course fills seats, needs at Harvard|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/11/26/computer-science-course-breaks-stereotypes-and-fills-halls-harvard/7XAXko7O392DiO1nAhp7dL/story.html|publisher=The Boston Globe}}</ref>
== Format == CS50 lectures are recorded and uploaded to several services including [[iTunes U]], edX (where it is known as CS50x), and YouTube. Additional video "walkthroughs" are recorded with professors and volunteer students. Course questions, called problem sets, or "psets" for short, are available in both PDF and HTML format. Students can upload problem set answers, and some questions are graded by automation. Students can also use special software to check their code in the [[Cloud computing|cloud]]. In 2016, CS50 became the first university course to offer students the possibility to watch all lectures entirely in [[virtual reality]].<ref>{{cite web|title=CS50 Moves Away from Traditional Lectures, Toward Virtual Reality|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2016/8/31/CS50-moves-from-lectures/|website=The Crimson|date=2016-08-31|author=Fahs, C. Ramsey}}</ref>
== Notable people == Professor [[David_Malan_(computer_scientist)|David Malan]] has been called one of the world's better-known computer science educators.<ref name=Feldt>{{cite news|last=Feldt|first=Brian|title=LaunchCode hackathon to feature global computer science educator|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/blog/biznext/2014/03/launchcode-hackathon-to-feature-global-computer.html?page=all|accessdate=2014-05-04|newspaper=St. Louis Business Journal|date=2014-03-11}}</ref> Both Facebook co-founder [[Mark Zuckerberg]] and former Microsoft chief executive officer [[Steve Ballmer]] have given guest lectures.<ref name=Zuckerberg>{{cite web|title=CS50 Guest Lecture by Mark Zuckerberg|url=http://dc.uwm.edu/zuckerberg_files_transcripts/141/|publisher=Harvard University}}</ref><ref name=Ballmer>{{cite web|title=CS50 Guest Lecture by Steve Ballmer|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7lhlKF6MECs|publisher=Harvard University}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://cs50.harvard.edu CS50 Official Web site] * [https://itunes.apple.com/us/course/this-is-cs50-2013./id786312091 CS50 on iTunes U] * [https://www.edx.org/course/introduction-computer-science-harvardx-cs50x CS50 course on EdX]
[[Category:Harvard University]] [[Category:Yale University]] [[Category:Computer science education]]

revision.text:
[[File:Christiane Woopen by-fotodimatti-1749.jpg|thumb|Prof. Dr. Christiane Woopen, Universität zu Köln (2015)]]
'''Christiane Woopen''' (born 12 December 1962) is a German medical ethicist. She was appointed Professor for Ethics and Theory of Medicine at the [[University of Cologne]] in 2009. There she is Executive Director of ceres (Cologne Center for Ethics, Rights, Economics, and Social Sciences of Health),<ref>{{Cite web|title = ceres: Home|url = http://www.ceres.uni-koeln.de|website = www.ceres.uni-koeln.de|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> an interdepartmental institution created by the Rector and five of the six Faculties of Cologne University. Furthermore, she is Head of the Research Unit Ethics at the Faculty of Medicine and Vice-Dean for Academic Development and Gender of that Faculty. From 2012 to 2016 she is Chair of the German Ethics Council<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.ethikrat.org/about-us/members/christiane-woopen|title = Biography Christiane Woopen at web site German Ethics Council|publisher = |accessdate = 7 February 2016}}</ref> and from 2014 to 2016 President of the [https://www.globalsummit-berlin2016.de Global Summit of National Ethics/Bioethics Committees].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Welcome to the Global Summit of National Ethics/Bioethics Committees 2016 in Berlin — Global Summit 2016|url = https://www.globalsummit-berlin2016.de|website = www.globalsummit-berlin2016.de|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref> She has been portrayed by various periodicals.<ref>{{Cite news|title = WERTE An der Schwelle|url = http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-88963882.html|newspaper = Der Spiegel|date = 2012-10-08|access-date = 2016-02-20|volume = 41|first = Markus|last = Feldenkirchen}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Eine Frau für letzte Fragen|url = http://www.focus.de/magazin/archiv/report-eine-frau-fuer-letzte-fragen_aid_833621.html|website = FOCUS Online|access-date = 2016-02-20|first = FOCUS (2012-10-08)|last = Online}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Christiane Woopen Sturmerprobte Katholikin|url = http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/portraets-personalien/im-portraet-die-vorsitzende-des-deutschen-ethikrates-christiane-woopen-13173880.html|newspaper = Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|date = 2014-09-26|access-date = 2016-02-20|issn = 0174-4909|language = German|first = Heike|last = Schmoll}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Das Gewissen der Nation - Christ und Welt|url = http://www.christundwelt.de/themen/detail/artikel/das-gewissen-der-nation/|website = www.christundwelt.de|access-date = 2016-02-20}}</ref>
==Education and professional work== Woopen received the degree of Doctor of Medicine in 1993 from [[Rheinische Friedrich-Wilhelms-University Bonn]]. After having worked as a doctor in gynecology and obstetrics Woopen changed her professional activities and focused on medical ethics. From 1990-1995 she studied philosophy in Bonn and Hagen.  In 2005, she received Habilitation and ''venia legendi'' for Ethics and Theory of Medicine, from the Faculty of Medicine at University of Cologne.
Her main research interests pertain to ethical questions in reproductive and prenatal medicine, neuroethics, health literacy and quality of life as well as the future of health care in times of digitalization.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Forschung — Deutsch|url = http://geschichte-ethik.uk-koeln.de/de/forschungsstelle-ethik/forschung|website = geschichte-ethik.uk-koeln.de|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> She mainly engages in inter- and transdisciplinary research projects, partly in international consortia.
== Memberships == Woopen is member in numerous advisory bodies.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Gremien — Deutsch|url = http://geschichte-ethik.uk-koeln.de/de/forschungsstelle-ethik/mitarbeiter/christiane-woopen/beratendetaetigkeit|website = geschichte-ethik.uk-koeln.de|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> Among others, she was member of the National Ethics Council (Germany) from 2001 to 2007, which then was converted to the German Ethics Council. There she was elected Deputy Chair from 2008-2012 and Chair from 2012-2016. Since 2010, she is member of the [[International Bioethics Committee|International Bioethics Committee of UNESCO]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0022/002274/227452M.pdf|title = COMPOSITION OF THE INTERNATIONAL BIOETHICS COMMITTEE OF UNESCO (IBC) (2014-2015)|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> At the Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care she is a member of the Scientific Advisory Board<ref>{{Cite web|title = iqwig.de - Mitglieder des Wissenschaftlichen Beirats|url = https://www.iqwig.de/de/ueber-uns/struktur-des-instituts/organe-und-gremien/mitglieder-des-wissenschaftlichen-beirats.2960.html|website = www.iqwig.de|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> and furthermore a member of the [[European Academy of Sciences and Arts]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = European Academy of Sciences and Arts|url = http://www.euro-acad.eu/members?filter=w&land=Germany&page=3|website = www.euro-acad.eu|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref>
==Publications and academic activities==
* Woopen, C.: Gesundheitskompetenz. In: Sturma, D., Heinrichs, B. (Hg.): Handbuch Bioethik. J.B. Metzler, Stuttgart 2015. * {{cite journal | last1 = Woopen | first1 = C | year = 2014 | title = Die Bedeutung von Lebensqualität aus ethischer Perspektive | url = | journal = Z Evid Fortbild Qual Gesundhwes | volume = 108 | issue = | pages = 140–145 | doi = 10.1016/j.zefq.2014.03.002 }} * Woopen, C.: Weimarer Reden 2014: Emanzipiert Euch! - Der ungebildete Kranke. Über Herrschaft und Beherrschung der Medizin - http://www.nationaltheater-weimar.de/de/index/spielplan/stuecke_extras/stuecke_details.php?SID=1403 - Audio http://www.nationaltheater-weimar.de/de/index/mediathek/mediathek_audio_extras.php#audio_1403 * {{cite journal | last1 = Woopen | first1 = C. | last2 = Pauls | first2 = A.K. | last3 = Koy | first3 = A. | last4 = Moro | first4 = E. | last5 = Timmermann | first5 = L. | year = 2013 | title = Early application of deep brain stimulation: Clinical and ethical issues | url = | journal = Progress in Neurobiology | volume = 110 | issue = | pages = 74–88 | doi = 10.1016/j.pneurobio.2013.04.002 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Woopen | first1 = C. | last2 = Timmermann | first2 = L. | last3 = Kuhn | first3 = J. | year = 2012 | title = An ethical framework for outcome assessment in psychiatric DBS | url = | journal = AJOB Neuroscience | volume = 3 | issue = 1| pages = 50–55 | doi = 10.1080/21507740.2011.635631 }} * Woopen, C.: Ethical Aspects of Neuromodulation. In Clement Hamani and Elena Moro (ed.): Emerging Horizons in Neuromodulation, Vol 107, International Review Neurobiology, UK: Academic Press, 2012 pp. 315–332. {{DOI|10.1016/B978-0-12-404706-8.00016-4}} * Woopen, C.: Der Arzt als Heiler und Manager. Zur erforderlichen Integration des scheinbar Unvereinbaren. In: Katzenmeier, C.; Bergdolt, K.: Das Bild des Arztes im 21. Jahrhundert. Springer, Heidelberg 2009, 181-194. * Woopen, C.: Solidarische Gesundheitsversorgung – Was schulden wir uns gegenseitig?  In: Schäfer, D.; Frewer, A.; Schockenhoff, E.; Wetzstein, V. (Hg.): Gesundheitskonzepte im Wandel.  Geschichte, Ethik und Gesellschaft.  Franz Steiner Verlag, Stuttgart 2008, 189-199. * Rohde, A., Woopen, C.: Psychosoziale Beratung im Kontext von Pränataldiagnostik.  Evaluation der Modellprojekte in Bonn, Düsseldorf und Essen. Deutscher Ärzteverlag, Köln 2007. * Woopen, C.: Selektion aufgrund genetischer Diagnostik? Handlungstheoretisch fundierte Güterethik und ihre Anwendung am Beispiel der Präimplantationsdiagnostik.  In: Honnefelder, L.; Streffer, C. (Hg.): Jahrbuch für Wissenschaft und Ethik, Band 10, de Gruyter, Berlin, New York 2005, 343-353.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://geschichte-ethik.uk-koeln.de/de/forschungsstelle-ethik/mitarbeiter/christiane-woopen/veroeffentlichungen List of publications] *[http://geschichte-ethik.uk-koeln.de/de/forschungsstelle-ethik/forschung List of research projects] *[https://www.munzinger.de/search/document?index=mol-00&id=00000030392&type=text/html&query.key=BFVLiTZG&template=/publikationen/personen/document.jsp&preview= Munzinger Biographies]
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
'''''Code Words''''' is an [[Electronic publishing|on-line publication]] about [[computer programming]] produced by the [[Recurse Center]] retreat community. It began publishing in December, 2014, and has a quarterly schedule.
The journal features original work by participants at the Center, including visiting “residents” and alumni. It is intended to “share the joyful approach to programming and learning that typifies” the community, and to be “accessible and useful to both new and seasoned programmers.”<ref name='blog-61'>{{cite web |url= https://www.recurse.com/blog/61-introducing-code-words |title= Introducing Code Words |author= Rachel Vincent |publisher= Recurse Center |work= Blog |date= December 5, 2014 |accessdate= November 28, 2016 }}</ref>
Topics commonly treated include the inner workings of programming tools such as [[Git]];<ref>{{cite web |url= https://codewords.recurse.com/issues/two/git-from-the-inside-out |title= Git from the inside out |author= Mary Rose Cook |publisher= Recurse Center |work= Code Words |date= March 2015 |accessdate= November 28, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://codewords.recurse.com/issues/three/unpacking-git-packfiles |title= Unpacking Git packfiles |author= Aditya Mukerjee |publisher= Recurse Center |work= Code Words |date= June 2015 |accessdate= November 28, 2016 }}</ref> Computer Science concepts such as [[propositional logic]],<ref>{{cite web |url= https://codewords.recurse.com/issues/four/the-language-of-choice |title= The language of choice |author= Darius Bacon |publisher= Recurse Center |work= Code Words |date= September 2015 |accessdate= November 28, 2016 }}</ref> [[data types]],<ref>{{cite web |url= https://codewords.recurse.com/issues/three/algebra-and-calculus-of-algebraic-data-types |title= The algebra (and calculus!) of algebraic data types |author= Joel Burget |publisher= Recurse Center |work= Code Words |date= June 2015 |accessdate= November 28, 2016 }}</ref> and [[random forests]];<ref>{{cite web |url= https://codewords.recurse.com/issues/seven/a-tour-of-random-forests |title= A tour of random forests |author= Nathan Epstein |publisher= Recurse Center |work= Code Words |date= October 2016 |accessdate= November 28, 2016 }}</ref> and treatments of diverse problems encountered in actual programming.
The supervising editor is [[Rachel Honor Vincent]], with individual articles co-edited by members of the community. Contributions are licensed under the [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license]].<ref name='blog-61' />
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://codewords.recurse.com/about/ Official website] * [https://codewords.recurse.com/issues/ List of issues]
[[Category:Academic publishing]] [[Category:Computer programming]] [[Category:Electronic publishing]]
{{compu-prog-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Cusanuswerk_Logo.svg|225x225px|thumb|Logo of the Cusanuswerk]]
The '''Cusanuswerk''' is one of the thirteen [[Germany|German]] sponsorship organizations financed by the [[Federal Ministry of Education and Research|Federal Ministry of Education and Research (Germany)]] to promote gifted students. It is headquartered in [[Bonn]].
== History == The Cusanuswerk was founded in 1956 under the authority of the [[German Bishops' Conference]]. Name giver of the organization is the medieval scholar [[Nicholas of Cusa]]. The aim of the Cusanuswerk is to promote gifted Catholic students until their university graduation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cusanuswerk.de/bewerbung/universitaeten/grundauswahlverfahren/|title=Startseite|trans-title=|language=German|author=|date=|work=Cusanuswerk.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref>
From 1988 to 1995, the Cusanuswerk was directed by [[Annette Schavan]]; from 2004 to 2011 it was led by Josef Wohlmuth.<ref>Employees. http://www.cusanuswerk.de/wir-ueber-uns/mitarbeiter/</ref> On October 1, 2011, he was succeeded by Georg Braungart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cusanuswerk.de/de/startseite/archiv-aktuelles/detailansicht/deutsche-bischofskonferenz-beruft-neuen-leiter-fuer-das-cusanuswerk/|title=Startseite|trans-title=|language=German|author=|date=|work=Cusanuswerk.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref> Auxiliary bishop Christoph Hegge, [[Münster]], is the commissary of the German Bishops' Conference for the Cusanuswerk since 2013.
== Stipend and support == The Cusanuswerk awards public funds to "particularly gifted catholic students of all disciplines."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cusanuswerk.de/de/startseite/bischoefliche-studienfoerderung/|title=Startseite|trans-title=|language=German|author=|date=|work=Cusanuswerk.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref>
=== Application === For admission, candidates have to apply at the organization or suggested for application by university lecturers or high school teachers.
The selection is a multi-step procedure. At its end, around one quarter of all applicants will be admitted. Admission depends on three main criteria including academic performance, [[Volunteering|social engagement]] and catholic denomination. Admission is possible starting at the entrance to university but also at later stages as long as five semesters of standard study period remain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cusanuswerk.de/de/bewerbung/ueberblick/|title=Startseite|trans-title=|language=German|author=|date=|work=Cusanuswerk.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref>
An annual exhibition is organized for applicants studying arts, displaying works of all nominated applicants.
=== Financial support === Financial support is subject to the rules by the Federal Ministry of Education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bmbf.de/de/294.php|title=Die Begabtenförderungswerke - BMBF|trans-title=|language=German|first=|last=BMBF-Internetredaktion|date=|work=BMBF.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref> It consists of either a fixed monthly lump-sum or a more generous means-tested scholarship for students in need, similar to the regulations of the [[Bundesausbildungsförderungsgesetz|BAföG]]. Doctoral students receive a scholarship independent of their financial background.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cusanuswerk.de/foerderung/stipendien/|title=Startseite|trans-title=|language=German|author=|date=|work=Cusanuswerk.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref> Additional support is available for study and research stays abroad.
=== Academic support === The academic support includes regular educational events as well as a spiritual enrichment program. It is expected that support recipients attend an annual summer school organized by the Cusanuswerk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cusanuswerk.de/programm/ueberblick/|title=Startseite|trans-title=|language=German|author=|date=|work=Cusanuswerk.de|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref>
During their studies, Cusanuswerk scholarship holders form groups at the location of their college. An appointed liaison professor provides additional support. All local scholarship groups elect representatives. Representatives of all local groups meet semiannually for a joint assembly (Cusanerkonferenz).
Social engagement and the acquisition of international experience are particularly encouraged for scholarship holders.
The Cusanuswork also offers special career support for women based on mentorships and additional seminars.
== Prominent former scholarship holders (so-called Altcusaner) == * [[Adolf M. Birke]], university professor, historian * [[Brun-Otto Bryde]], former judge at the Federal Constitutional Court * [[Michael F. Feldkamp]], historian * [[Winfried Hassemer]], university professor, jurist, former judge at the Federal Constitutional Court * [[Willi Jäger]], university professor, mathematician * [[Paul Kirchhof]], university professor, jurist, former judge at the Federal Constitutional Court * [[Christoph Klein]], paediatrician and university professor * [[Oskar Lafontaine]], former chairmain of the [[SPD]], former minister president of [[Saarland]], member of the [[Bundestag]] (Faction DIE LINKE.) * [[Norbert Lammert]], member of the Bundestag, president of the Bundestag since 2005 * [[Johannes Masing]], university professor, jurist, judge at the Federal Constitutional Court * [[Michael Matheus]], university professor * [[Heinz Riesenhuber]], former federal minister of research and technology * [[Ferdi Schüth]], university professor, chemist * [[Hans Tietmeyer]], former president of the [[Deutsche Bundesbank]]
== Literature == * ''Begabung als Herausforderung''. Editors: Hermann Breulmann, Wolfgang Frühwald, [[Annette Schavan]], Paderborn, Munich, Vienna, Zurich 1991. * ''Verbindende Vielfalt. 40 Jahre Cusanuswerk''. Editor: Claudia Lücking-Michel, Köln 1996 * ''50 Jahre Cusanuswerk. Bischöfliche Studienförderung. Glauben. Wissen. Gestalten 1956-2006'', Publisher: Cusanuswerk. Bonn 2006.
== References == <references />
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.cusanuswerk.de/}}
[[Category:Scholarships in Germany]] [[Category:1956 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Education in Germany]] [[Category:Organisations based in Bonn]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1956]]

'''Dale H. Schunk''' is an [[educational psychology|educational psychologist]], former Dean and current professor in the School of Education at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. He has researched the effects of social and instructional variables on [[cognition]], [[learning]], [[self-regulated learning|self-regulation]] and [[motivation]]. Schunk has served on the editorial boards of journals such as ''[[Contemporary Educational Psychology]]'' and ''[[Educational Psychology Review]]'', and has authored many journal articles and book chapters on educational psychology. In addition to other books, he is author of the widely used textbook, ''Learning Theories: An Educational Perspective'', and coauthor of ''Motivation in Education: Theory Research and Applications''.
Schunk received the Albert J. Harris Research Award from the International Reading Association (1989), an Early Contributions Award from Division 15 (Educational Psychology) of the American Psychological Association (1982), and the Fulbright Distinguished American Scholar Award (1997). Before moving to Purdue, Schunk taught educational psychology at the [[University of Houston]] from 1979 to 1985 and at [[UNC-Chapel Hill]] from 1986 to 1993. He received his undergraduate education at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois]], and he earned an M.Ed. degree from [[Boston University]] and a [[Ph.D.]] from the [[Stanford Graduate School of Education]].
==Selected recent publications==
* Schunk, D. H. (2005). "Self-regulated learning: The educational legacy of [[Paul Pintrich|Paul R. Pintrich]]". ''Educational Psychologist, 40'', 85-94. * Schunk, D. H. (2003). "Self-efficacy for reading and writing: Influence of modeling, goal setting, and self-evaluation". ''Reading and Writing Quarterly, 19'', 159-172. * Schunk, D. H. (2000). "Motivation for achievement: Past, present, and future". ''Issues in Education: Contributions from Educational Psychology, 6'', 161-165. * Schunk, D. H. (2000). "Coming to terms with motivation constructs". ''Contemporary Educational Psychology, 25'' (116-119). * Schunk, D. H., & Ertmer, P. A. (1999). "Self-regulatory processes during computer skill acquisition: Goal and self-evaluative influences". ''Educational Psychology, 91'', 251-260. * Schunk, D. H. (1999). "Social-self interaction and achievement behavior". ''Educational Psychologist, 34'', 219-227. * Schunk, D. H. (1998). "An educational psychologist's perspective on cognitive neuroscience". ''Educational Psychology Review, 10'', 411-417. * Schunk, D. H., & Zimmerman, B. J. (1997). "Social origins of self-regulatory competence". ''Educational Psychologist, 32'', 195-208. * Schunk, D. H., & Cutshall, D. (1997). "Motivation for lifelong learning". ''Kappa Delta Pi Record, 33'', 124-128.
==External links== * [http://www.uncg.edu/soe/ncate/faculty/ted/Schunk,%20Dale%20H.pdf Dale Schunk CV]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Schunk, Dale}} [[Category:Educational psychologists]] [[Category:Stanford Graduate School of Education alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Undisclosed paid|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox website | name = | logo = EduKartlogo.png | logocaption = EduKart logo | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://www.edukart.com}} | slogan = | commercial = Yes | type = [[Online education]] | registration = Required | language = English | num_users = | owner = [[Ishan Gupta]] | author = Ishan Gupta | editor = | launch_date = {{Start date and age|2011|11|df=yes}} | alexa = {{flagicon|India}} 29,845(as of September 2016)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/edukart.com# |title= EduKart.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2013-09-16 }}</ref> | revenue = | current_status = Active | footnotes = }} '''EduKart''' is an [[India]]n [[higher education]] enrollment platform.<ref>{{cite news|title=Best Higher Education Platform: EduKart|url=http://www.siliconindia.com/magazine-articles-in/Best_Higher_Education_Platform_EduKart-JGTQ826859595.html|accessdate=4 February 2015}}</ref> Indian and international course providers offer programs such as MBA, Executive MBA, MCA, MSc IT, MA, MCom, BA, BCom BBA, BCA and BSc IT on the company platform. The courses are available as [[distance learning]] and [[online courses]]. It also features [[Certificate in Education|certificate courses]] in areas of [[retail]], [[finance]], [[Telecommunication|telecom]], [[digital marketing]], [[programming languages]], [[project management]], and [[Information Technology|IT]].
==Overview== EduKart offers degrees, diploma and certificate courses from universities, institutions and industry bodies. It is part of a growing trend in the region<ref>{{cite web|last=Punj |first=Deepshikha |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/education/edex/article1362466.ece |title=Shop for courses at these portals |publisher=The New Indian Express |date= |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref> with institutions and companies like [[Tamil Virtual Academy]],<ref>{{cite web|last= |first= |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/tamil-virtual-academy/article7801568.ece |title=Tamil Virtual Academy |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date= |accessdate=}}</ref> [[Transweb]] and Bookmytrainings offering courses from Indian and international course providers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/education/edex/2011/jul/25/one-stop-shop-for-training-needs-275137.html |title=One-stop shop for training needs |website= |date=2011-07-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bookmytrainings.com |title=Bookmytrainings – Home |website= |access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/education/jain-university-conducts-2day-job-fair/article8454892.ece |title=Jain University conducts 2-day job fair |website=The Hindu Business Line |access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref> There are some certifications which have been created by EduKart team along with some industry experts and are recognized by industry bodies.
EduKart has partnerships with universities, both national Narsee Monjee Institute of Management Studies – School for Continuing Education Bharathi Vidyapeeth, [[Indian School of Business]], University of Petroleum and Energy Studies and international ([[Northwood University]], [[London School of Business and Finance]]).<ref>{{cite web | title = Indian Education goes global as EduKart launches international degrees| author= | publisher = | date = 2013-06-09 | url = http://www.educationworld.in/news/corporate/indian-education-goes-global-as-edukart-launches-international-degrees.html | accessdate = 2013-09-16}}</ref> [[Concordia University Chicago]]. The degrees awarded by the Indian universities are recognized by the [[University Grants Commission (India)|University Grants Commission]] and those awarded by the international universities hold the same value as the equivalent degrees earned in a traditional campus environment. The certificate course providers include [[Internet and Mobile Association of India]],<ref>{{cite web | title = EduKart.com and Computer Society of India launch Online Certificate Courses in Programming Languages| author= | publisher = | date = 2013-02-28 | url = http://clickitnews.co.in/?p=7694 | accessdate = 2013-09-21}}</ref> [[Computer Society of India]],<ref>{{cite web | title = EduKart.com, Retail Assoc launch mgt courses online | author= | publisher = [[Business Standard]]| date = 2012-09-07 | url = http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/edukart-com-retail-assoc-launch-mgt-courses-online-112041100140_1.html | accessdate = 2013-09-20}}</ref> Retailers Association of India,<ref>{{cite web | title = EduKart And AIWMI Launch Certificate Course In Financial Management | author= | publisher = | date = 2013-04-05 | url = http://www.prlog.org/12113006-edukart-and-aiwmi-launch-certificate-course-in-financial-management.html | accessdate = 2013-09-20}}</ref> Vskills (Govt. of India),<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.telegraphindia.com/external/display.jsp?mode=details&id=38579|title = EduKart Partners with Vskills to Promote Government Certifications|last = |first = |date = |work = |access-date = }}</ref> Enhelion, GIIP and more.
EduKart provides job placement assistance through its job portal on the website.
==History== The aim of EduKart was to bring more flexibility into the [[Higher education in India|Indian education system]]. It was started by Ishan Gupta and Mayank Gupta in 2011.<ref>http://www.iimnet.com/profiles/blogs/edukart</ref><ref>http://insideiim.com/the-insideiim-entrepreneurship-series-interview-with-mayank-gupta-co-founder-edukart-com/</ref>
In May 2013, EduKart secured $500,000 in funding from a consortium of early-stage institutional and angel investors. The group includes Kima Ventures, Amit Patni and Arihant Patni, AKM Systems (Shiven Malhotra), Vibhor Mehra and alumni from Stanford University.<ref>{{cite web | title = Being in Koramangala got us visibility in right circles: Ishan Gupta, CEO, Edukart| author= | publisher = [[The Economic Times]]| date = 2013-09-09 | url = http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-09-09/news/41903520_1_education-hub-edukart-koramangla| accessdate = 2013-09-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = EduKart raises $500,000 to make waves in India’s online education market | author= Robin Wauters | publisher = The Next Web| date = 2013-05-30 | url = https://thenextweb.com/insider/2013/05/30/edukart-raises-500000-to-crack-indias-online-education-market/| accessdate = 2013-09-16}}</ref>
In 2016, Edukart was acquired by Paytm and this deal was said to involve an employment contract.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/eXC2XlTfAqBVS8yGEP7VGO/Paytm-buys-edutech-startup-Edukart.html|title=Paytm buys edutech start-up Edukart|last=Chakraborty|first=Sayan|date=2016-09-26|work=livemint.com/|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/companies/paytm-acquires-edukarta-no-cash-consideration-deal-961639.html|title=Paytm acquires Edukart in a no cash consideration deal|website=Moneycontrol|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.edukart.com}} * [http://www.conflatingvisions.com/2017/08/indian-education-startups-online-learning-india/ Indian Education Startups making it big – How India is getting adapted to the concept of Online Learning!]
{{MOOC}}
