page.title: National Association of Student Personnel Administrators

revision.comment: no external links in article body per [[WP:EL]]
revision.text:
{{Advert|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox organization | name= National Association of Student Personnel Administrators | image= NASPA.png | formation= {{start date|1919|01}}, [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]], [[Wisconsin]], [[United States]] | founders= Robert Rienow, [[Thomas Arkle Clark]] | headquarters = 111 K Street NE, [[Washington, D.C.]], United States | fields= [[Student affairs]] | membership= 13,000 members | membership_year= 2015 | leader_title= President | leader_name= Kevin Kruger | staff= 40 | staff_year = 2015 | mission= To be the principal source of leadership, scholarship, professional development, and advocacy for student affairs. | website= {{url|naspa.org}} | formerly= Conference of Deans and Advisers of Men (CDAM) (1919-1929)
National Association of Deans and Advisers of Men (NADAM) (1929-51) }} The '''National Association of Student Personnel Administrators''' is a U.S.-based student affairs organization boasting more than 13,000 members at 1,400 campuses, and 25 countries.{{cite web |title = About NASPA|publisher = NASPA|url = https://www.naspa.org/about|accessdate = 2015-09-25}} Founded in 1919 at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin]], NASPA is one of many organizations focused on [[graduate enrollment management]]. == History == [[Image:Universal North Building.JPG|thumbnail|right|NASPA headquarters in Washington, D.C.]] In December 1918, Robert Rienow, the dean of men at the [[University of Iowa]] desired to create a meeting that would bring together various [[Dean of Men|deans of men]] in the midwest. He, with [[Thomas Arkle Clark]], dean of men at the [[University of Illinois]], facilitated the founding meeting held at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] in January 1919. The first meeting was quite small - three deans of men and three professors having campus interests were in attendance.{{cite web | author = Rhatigan, James J. | title = NASPA History | publisher = NASPA | year = 1989 | url = http://www.naspa.org/about/history.cfm | accessdate = 2007-09-09}} Professor Louis A. Strauss of the [[University of Michigan]] referred to the first meeting as the "Conference of Deans and Advisers of Men." This label was used in prevalence until 1929 when it was changed to the National Association of Deans and Advisers of Men (NADAM). The new name was more fitting because many American universities did not have the "Dean of Men" title. Thomas Arkle Clark was the first person to claim the title in 1909, although he assumed the responsibilities in 1901.{{cite web | title = Thomas Arkle Clark Award | publisher = Alpha Tau Omega | url = http://www.ato.org/nat/awd_tac.shtml | accessdate = 2008-06-27}} Scott Goodnight, dean of men at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], served as host for this historic first meeting. Retroactively, he is referred to as the first president of NADAM. In 1925, the first piece of "research" - presented by John Bennett of Teachers College, [[Columbia University]] - was offered at a NADAM meeting. It dealt with the prevalence of the office of dean of men in American colleges and universities. The last meeting of the '20s was the first to be conducted away from the college campus; there were 76 participants, each paying dues of $10. In the 1930s, there were continued requests for publications to be submitted to the conferences. The ''NASPA Journal'', as a result, was first introduced in 1963. Before that time, newsletters were the primary way of communicating regarding published material. One of the Association's major preoccupations in the 1940s was [[World War II]] and its aftermath. The adaptation of campuses to the war effort are reflected in the conference minutes, and the problems relating to veterans once the war was over took the rest of the decade. The decade was noted by the presence of Armour Blackburn of [[Howard University]], the first African-American administrator to participate and serve on an executive committee. As student affairs offices began to change and administrators no longer used "Dean of Men" and "Advisor of Men" as their titles, the organization followed suit. Mary Ethel Ball, acting dean of students at the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]], became the first female "institutional representative," although women had participated in meetings since the 20s. Dean Wesley P. Lloyd at [[Brigham Young University]] recommended a name change in 1951 to the National Association of Student Personnel Administrators (NASPA). This gave a new breadth to the organization, which stated its purpose: "to discuss and study the most effective methods of aiding students in their intellectual, social, moral, and personal development". Five commissions were established at the 1951 conference to deal with substantive, ongoing issues (e.g., professional relationships, [[ethics]], [[Professional Development|professional preparation]]). A secondary benefit of the commissions was in making more members able to participate in the association's activities. The 1960s marked many changes in NASPA. For the first time, outside funding was secured for a NASPA activity, making the association an early leader in educating members concerning [[drug abuse]]. NASPA was an active participant in the development of the Joint Statement on [[Rights]] and Freedoms of Students. From 1966 until the end of the decade and beyond, crisis was the most prominent [[campus]] issue and the most prominent association concern. Some deans were enormously successful in protecting both their campuses and the rights of students, but disruption of campuses became more prevalent. During the 1970s, increased regionalization heightened opportunities for involvement across the whole spectrum of NASPA's membership. Alice Manicur of Frostbug State College became the first female president, and community colleges began to make their presence felt. George Young at [[Broward Community College]] was the first [[community college]] person to serve as president of NASPA. It was during this decade that NASPA first established a national office under the leadereship of Channing Briggs at [[Portland State University]]. Upon Briggs' retirement in 1981, Richard F. Stevens became the second [[executive director]], and the national office was moved to [[Ohio State University]]. In 1985, the association voted to move its headquarters to [[Washington, D.C.]], and in 1987 Elizabeth M. Nuss of [[Indiana University]], succeeded Stevens. In 1995, Gwendolyn Dungy succeeded Nuss. In 2000 the [[National Association for Women in Education]] was merged into NASPA.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IegaBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA187&dq=National+Association+for+Women+in+Education&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBWoVChMIpraG0uPlxgIVyckUCh1Z3QYO#v=onepage&q=National%20Association%20for%20Women%20in%20Education&f=false|title=Deans of Women and the Feminist Movement: Emily Taylor's Activism|date=December 2014|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=113748134X|page=187|author=Kelly C. Sartorius|accessdate=19 August 2015}} Laurence Smith, Vice President for Student Affairs and Enrollment Management at [[Eastern Michigan University]], initiated the concept of the Centers for Innovation in February 2000, proposing centers for [[leadership]], [[policy|public policy]], [[research]], and [[technology]] to guide professional development for the association. {{cite web | author = Tuttle, Kathryn Nemeth | title = Recent History | publisher = NASPA | date = May 6, 2008 | url = http://www.naspa.org/about/history2.cfm | accessdate = 2008-09-14}} ==References== {{Student Affairs Associations}} {{DEFAULTSORT:National Association Of Student Personnel Administrators}} [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1919]] [[Category:1919 establishments in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Education-related professional associations]]

{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox government agency | agency_name = National Civics Bureau
Biro Tata Negara
BTN | logo = [[File:Official logo of Biro Tata Negara.svg|200px|Biro Tata Negara]] | image has rationale=yes | agency_type = | formed = 1981 | dissolved = 2018 | jurisdiction = [[Government of Malaysia]] | services = Nurturing spirit of patriotism and doctrination of nationalism. | motto = | website = {{URL|http://www.btn.gov.my/}} }} The '''National Civics Bureau''' ({{lang-ms|Biro Tata Negara}}), abbreviated '''BTN''', was an [[Government agency|agency]] of the Malaysian previous ruling [[government of Malaysia|government]] under [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN) coalition in the [[Prime Minister's Department]]. It was established in 1974 as the Youth Research Unit (Unit Penyelidikan Belia) under the Youth Ministry, but was renamed and transferred in 1981. BTN's stated objective is to nurture the spirit of patriotism and commitment to excellence among Malaysians, and train leaders and future leaders to support the nation's development efforts.{{cite web |title=Latar Belakang |url=http://www.btn.gov.my/v2/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=351&Itemid=41 |accessdate=21 November 2009 |publisher=Biro Tata Negara |language=Malay}} BTN's programmes are controversial, and many accuse them of explicitly promoting ''[[ketuanan Melayu]]'' and the former governing coalition [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN).{{cite web |author=Lim Kit Siang |title=Any Najib apology for the rank racism of BTN indoctrination courses? |url=http://blog.limkitsiang.com/2008/09/04/any-najib-apology-for-the-rank-racism-of-btn-indoctrination-courses/ |work=The New Straits Times |date=4 September 2008 |accessdate=11 May 2009}}{{cite news |title=Anwar trains his sights on 1 Malaysia |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/25013-anwar-trains-his-sights-on-1-malaysia |work=The Malaysian Insider |date=30 April 2009 |accessdate=26 November 2009}}{{cite web |author=Azly Rahman |title=Create radical social futurists, dismantle Biro Tata Negara -- that threat to national unity |url=http://malaysia-today.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=28726:create-radical-social-futurists-dismantle-biro-tata-negara-that-threat-to-national-unity&catid=1:a-republic-of-virtue&Itemid=100088 |work=Malaysia Today |date=26 November 2009 |accessdate=27 November 2009}} On 25 November 2009, the [[Selangor]] state government issued a ban prohibiting state civil servants, employees of state subsidiaries, and students at state-owned institutions from attending BTN courses.{{cite news |author=Tan Yi Liang |title=Selangor boycotts Biro Tata Negara programmes |url=http://www.thesundaily.com/article.cfm?id=40637 |work=The Sun Daily |date=25 November 2009 |accessdate=27 November 2009}}{{cite news|author=Mazlinda Mahmood |title=No Biro Tatanegara courses for Selangor govt employees |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/articles/8ku/Article/index_html |work=The New Straits Times |date=26 November 2009 |accessdate=27 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127134134/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/articles/8ku/Article/index_html |archivedate=27 November 2009 }} On 2 December 2009, the [[Penang]] state government followed suit and banned all state civil servants from attending the controversial courses.{{cite news |title=Penang bans civil servants from attending BTN courses |url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/32309 |work=Sin Chew |date=2 December 2009 |accessdate=14 December 2009}} On 13 August 2018, Youth and Sports Minister [[Syed Saddiq Syed Abdul Rahman]] from the new federal government under [[Pakatan Harapan]] (PH) announced that the BTN and [[National Service Training Programme (Malaysia)|National Service Training Programme]] (PLKN) were abolished.[https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2018/08/13/syed-saddiq-btn-and-national-service-are-abolished/ Syed Saddiq: BTN and National Service are abolished][https://www.malaymail.com/s/1661883/syed-saddiq-btn-national-service-abolished Syed Saddiq: BTN, National Service abolished] ==Allegations of racism== Although BTN has been the subject of various allegations over the years, in late 2009, it became the subject of greater controversy, when many allegations of racism and political propaganda appeared in quick succession. One BTN alumnus claimed that he was "taught a song with lyrics like 'the land that you walk upon is owned by others'. Lecturers told us the [[Malay people|Malays]] were forced to depend on the [[Chinese Malaysian|Chinese]] for support after 1998 because some Malays had betrayed their own race," in reference to Malays voting against the [[Barisan Nasional]] in [[Malaysian general election, 1999|1999 general election]]. [[Nik Nazmi Nik Ahmad]], another alumnus and assemblyman for Seri Setia in the [[Selangor State Assembly|State Legislative Assembly of Selangor]], claimed that the BTN camp he attended was "racial and political in nature," with trainers telling attendees that Malays require [[affirmative action]] and criticising the opposition [[Parti Islam SeMalaysia]] (PAS) as "deviationist". Amirudin Shari, assemblyman for [[Batu Caves]], claimed that "participants are indoctrinated with propaganda about '[[Ketuanan Melayu]]' and external threats".{{cite news |title=KL patriotism camps ‘racist and political’ |url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/44127-kl-patriotism-camps-racist-and-political |work=The Malaysian Insider |date=21 November 2009 |accessdate=21 November 2009}} Another alumnus claims he was taught that the Chinese were "the Jews of Asia," and part of a [[Conspiracy (political)|conspiracy]] to topple the government.{{cite news | first=Asrul Hadi | last=Abdullah Sani | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=‘BTN taught me the Chinese are the Jews of Asia’ | date=27 November 2009 | publisher=The Malaysian Insider | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/44775-btn-taught-me-the-chinese-are-the-jews-of-asia | work = | pages = | accessdate = 27 November 2009 | language = }} Another alumnus alleged she was "told that the Malays were the most supreme race in the world, we were God's chosen few, that the others were insignificant. We were warned about certain elements in our society and abroad, determined to undermine Malay excellence."{{cite news | first=Mariam | last=Mokhtar | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=BTN: Divisive, racist, {{Sic|hide=y|politically|-}}motivated | date=5 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://malaysiakini.com/news/119070 | work =Malaysiakini | pages = | accessdate = 7 December 2009 | language = }} On 21 November 2009, Nik Nazmi, Amirudin and five other [[Pakatan Rakyat]] state assemblymen asked the Selangor government to stop requiring students at its universities and colleges to attend BTN courses. After the Selangor government issued a ban prohibiting state employees and students at state institutions from attending BTN programmes, the State Executive Councillor for Education, Dr. Halimah Ali, described the courses as "indoctrination by the Barisan Nasional government" and said, "the courses promote racism and my own children who have attended BTN have been given booklets that encourage hate towards the opposition."{{cite news |first=Neville |last=Spykerman |title=Selangor moves to stop BTN ‘brainwashing’ | date=26 November 2009 |url=http://themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/44582-selangor-moves-to-stop-btn-brainwashing |work=The Malaysian Insider |accessdate=26 November 2009}} In September 2010, BTN deputy director Hamim Husin was reported for referring Chinese as ''Si mata pepet'' (the slant-eyed) and Indians as ''Si botol'' (the drinkers) during a closed-door function of Puteri UMNO (Women youth wing of [[United Malays National Organisation]]) delegates.{{cite news|last1=Su Lyn|first1=Boo|title=Malays must rule the country, says BTN rep|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/malays-must-rule-the-country-says-btn-rep#sthash.hm9a6NCx.dpbs|accessdate=21 June 2015|publisher=The Malaysian Insider|date=27 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526175152/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/malays-must-rule-the-country-says-btn-rep|archivedate=26 May 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Kashuerin|first1=Suresh|title=Kit Siang: Racist BTN should be dissolved|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/19/kit-siang-racist-btn-should-be-dissolved/|accessdate=21 June 2015|publisher=Free Malaysia Today|date=19 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150621211148/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/19/kit-siang-racist-btn-should-be-dissolved/|archivedate=21 June 2015}} In November 2010, Minister in Prime Minister's department [[Mohamed Nazri Abdul Aziz|Nazri Aziz]] reported that the deputy director has been suspended from duty since October 2010 and a warning letter has been issued. However, the duration of suspension was not disclosed.{{cite news|title=Si sepet, si kaki botol, pegawai rasis digantung (Si sepet, Si kaki botol, racist employee is suspended)|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/147567|accessdate=21 June 2015|publisher=Malaysiakini|date=8 November 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110530150545/http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/147567|archivedate=30 May 2011}} ==Response by the Malaysian government== ''The Malaysian Insider'' reported in November 2009 that in response to brewing controversy, the [[Cabinet of Malaysia|Cabinet]] had discussed the need to revamp BTN. Minister in the Prime Minister's Department [[Idris Jala]] arranged a briefing for the Cabinet on the effects of BTN programmes, and the meeting concluded with the Prime Minister reportedly saying, "This must end." In an editorial, the publication said: "''The Malaysian Insider'' understands that there are moves within the administration to dilute the syllabus of BTN courses, as a compromise. But such half-measures are not likely to be enough if Najib is serious about reversing what many Malaysians see as institutionalised racism."{{cite news | first=Leslie | last=Lau | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Najib’s BTN dilemma | date=28 November 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/44845-pkr-najib-faces-btn-dilemma | work =The Malaysian Insider | pages = | accessdate = 29 November 2009 | language = }} Former [[Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Malay titles|Tan Sri]] [[Muhyiddin Yassin]] defended BTN, saying its programmes inculcate nationalism and unity among Malaysians in line with the Prime Minister's [[1Malaysia]] concept.{{cite news |title=DPM defends BTN courses against racist brainwashing charges |url=http://themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/44692-muhyiddin-btn-courses-not-political-indoctrination |work=The Malaysian Insider |date=26 November 2009 |accessdate=27 November 2009}}{{cite news |title=BTN Courses Not Political Indoctrination - Muhyiddin |url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=458094 |work=BERNAMA |date=26 November 2009 |accessdate=27 November 2009}} Subsequently, Deputy Minister in the Prime Minister's Department [[Malay titles|Datuk]] [[Ahmad Maslan]] said "knowledge and information ... presented at these courses are based on historical facts and data ... collected from various agencies and ... experts" and are consistent with 1Malaysia.{{cite news |title='Teaching based on historical facts and data' |url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=458094 |work=The New Straits Times |date=27 November 2009 |accessdate=27 November 2009}} Ahmad, who is also head of the BTN, denied allegations that it was systemically racist: "Out of the 1,000 lectures given, maybe only one minute the lecturer had a slip-up so it is unfair that you portray BTN as racist just for that." Describing typical course contents, he said participants "are taught about the Federal Constitution, the social contract, the position of the Malays in this country and 60 per cent of the population are the bumiputras." Although Minister in the Prime Minister's Department [[Nazri Aziz]] previously told the press that the Cabinet had ordered a revamp of BTN courses to eliminate elements inconsistent with 1Malaysia, Ahmad denied this, saying that Cabinet merely wanted an "upgrade" as opposed to a "revamp".{{cite news | first=Syed Jaymal | last=Zahiid | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=More flip-flop as BTN chief speaks out | date=1 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45128-more-flip-flop-as-btn-chief-speaks-out- | work =The Malaysian Insider | pages = | accessdate = 1 December 2009 | language = }} Responding, Nazri insisted that "Whatever word you use, upgrade or revamp ... to me, it is a change of module. Datuk Ahmad Masalan is a member of the Cabinet, he can’t dispute my statement." Nazri also criticised the denial of allegations against BTN, saying that opposition members who had previously been in government like Leader of the Opposition [[Anwar Ibrahim]] "know, so what is there to deny?" and said that BTN had been used to promote certain political leaders.{{cite news | first=Syed Jaymal | last=Zahiid | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Nazri says no point denying what BTN is | date=1 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45161-nazri-says-no-point-denying-what-btn-is- | work =The Malaysian Insider | pages = | accessdate = 1 December 2009 | language = }} ==Mahathir's involvement in BTN== Former Prime Minister [[Mahathir Mohamad]] defended BTN as meant to inculcate the values of discipline and hard work in public servants and scholars: "What we tried to teach them is that they should have new values, new culture...because the culture and the value-system they have is not conducive to success. If they want to serve the government well, they must accept and practice a certain value system."{{cite news | first=Shazwan | last=Mustafa Kamal | coauthors= | authorlink= | title=Dr M says criticisms against BTN an ‘exaggeration’ | date=7 December 2009 | publisher= | url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45729-dr-m-says-criticisms-against-btn-an-exaggeration- | work=The Malaysian Insider | pages= | accessdate=7 December 2009 | language= | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212223735/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45729-dr-m-says-criticisms-against-btn-an-exaggeration- | archivedate=12 December 2009 | df=dmy-all }} The ruling party-owned ''[[Utusan Malaysia]]'' newspaper criticised the decision to change the BTN curriculum, claiming Nazri was acting on his own and urging the government not to "bow down" to the opposition.{{cite news | first=Asrul Hadi | last=Abdullah Sani | coauthors= | authorlink= | title=Nazri calls Dr M a racist for defending BTN | date=7 December 2009 | publisher= | url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45724-nazri-calls-dr-m-a-racist-for-defending-btn | work=The Malaysian Insider | pages= | accessdate=7 December 2009 | language= | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212223732/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45724-nazri-calls-dr-m-a-racist-for-defending-btn | archivedate=12 December 2009 | df=dmy-all }} In response, Nazri branded Mahathir's statement "bloody racist," criticising both him and ''Utusan Malaysia'' for denying the allegations against BTN: {{quote|Don't think that people outside do not know about the syllabus based on patriotism for Malays. ... They all know what the syllabus is all about so who are we to say that it did not happen? You want to lie? You make people laugh. I mean there are people who attended the courses who came out very angry. There were many instances of the use of words like ''ketuanan Melayu''. It is ridiculous... Do they want to say that Malaysia belongs only to the Malays and the government is only a Malay government? Should only the Malays be given the spirit of patriotism? Other races are not patriotic about their country?}} Nazri denied that criticism from Pakatan Rakyat or the Selangor government decision were reasons for the Cabinet decision, saying: "...courses run by BTN using public funds must be used properly and it amounts to millions so if you want to talk about patriotism, patriotism for all, not just the Malays, for all Malaysians. It's not because of the Selangor state government that we changed the syllabus so it's long before that." In response, Mahathir accused Nazri of hypocrisy, saying "I must be a racist if Nazri says I am racist. Don't ever say that I am not. He knows everything. He belongs to a party which is racist... which is [[United Malays National Organisation|Umno]]. ... Umno is a party ''perkauman'' [racism] and is meant only for Malays and nobody [else] can join. So he (Nazri) is in a racist party but says he is against racism. So he should resign from the party." Mahathir is a former President of Umno, and was still a member of it and the time of making the statement.{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=You belong to a racist party: Dr M to Nazri | date=8 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://malaysiakini.com/news/119320 | work =Malaysiakini | pages = | accessdate = 11 December 2009 | language = }} [[Koh Tsu Koon]], another Minister in the Prime Minister's Department, defended Nazri, saying perhaps Mahathir was unaware of the nature of BTN's curriculum: "[R]ecent feedback from participants since last year showed that the BTN course has diverted from its earlier version. Participants, including JPA [Public Services Department] scholars, felt very upset and disheartened."{{cite news | first=G. | last=Manimaran | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Nazri finds another backer in tiff with Dr M | date=8 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45862-nazri-finds-another-backer-in-tiff-with-dr-m | work =The Malaysian Insider | pages = | accessdate = 11 December 2009 | language = }} Former BTN director and Member of Parliament for [[Sungai Petani]], [[Johari Abdul]] then alleged that Mahathir was responsible for changes in the BTN programme, saying that under Mahathir, BTN courses emphasised propaganda supportive of the ruling party, making claims such as "If the Umno-BN government falls, then ... the Malays would be enslaved in their own country."{{cite news | first=Syed Jaymal | last=Zahiid | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Dr M transformed BTN to a super-racist agency, says former director | date=8 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45873-dr-m-transformed-btn-to-a-super-racist-agency-says-former-director- | work =The Malaysian Insider | pages = | accessdate = 11 December 2009 | language = }} Other Members of Parliament, such as deputy chair of the Barisan Nasional Backbenchers Club and MP for [[Kinabatangan]], [[Bung Mokhtar Radin]], argued that BTN still served a useful purpose: "I don't see it as racist. It is one of the government agencies that have taught society the characteristics of a great nation and understand the real Malaysia. BTN has also played a role since independence towards strengthening racial harmony in this country. So I really regret the actions by Pakatan state governments to prohibit the activities by BTN because BTN has never had the intention to weaken any party members but it is a platform for the public to gain knowledge."{{cite news | first=Asrul Hadi | last=Abdullah Sani | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Umno backbenchers maintain BTN is not racist | date=9 December 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/45989-umno-backbenchers-maintain-btn-is-not-racist- | work =The Malaysian Insider | pages = | accessdate = 11 December 2009 | language = }} ==Leaked presentation slides == From 11 March 2015 until 15 June 2015, BTN had published a series of presentation slides which was available on its official website. One of the presentation slides had claimed [[Malay language|Malay]] [[Small press|independent publishers]] to be "anti-establishment", in which their "movement without supervision from the authorities" will "bring a negative effect on the government" and giving birth to "new icons of the young generation that spread extreme and free ideas". The slide had also recommended that government officials ban any books having "explicit and free" content produced by them.{{cite web|title=Gerakan Indie Di Malaysia (Indie Movement in Malaysia)|url=https://archive.org/details/GerakanIndieDiMalaysia|publisher=Biro Tata Negara|accessdate=23 June 2015|language=Malay}}{{cite news|title=BTN slaps bull’s-eye on Malay counterculture for anti-establishment bent|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/btn-slaps-bulls-eye-on-malay-counterculture-for-anti-establishment-bent|accessdate=23 June 2015|agency=Malay Mail online|date=15 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623143632/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/btn-slaps-bulls-eye-on-malay-counterculture-for-anti-establishment-bent|archivedate=23 June 2015}} This has raised ire from the publishers, who had collectively made a media statement demanding a public apology from the agency.{{cite news|title=Malay indie group strikes back at BTN, demands public apology|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/malay-indie-group-strikes-back-at-btn-demands-public-apology|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=The Malay Mail Online|date=20 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623144619/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/malay-indie-group-strikes-back-at-btn-demands-public-apology|archivedate=23 June 2015}} Following the incident, BTN decided to take down all the controversial slides from its website{{cite news|title=BTN removes slides from website after caught with pants down|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/btn-removes-slides-from-website-after-caught-with-pants-down|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=The Malay Mail Online|date=15 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150616175133/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/btn-removes-slides-from-website-after-caught-with-pants-down|archivedate=16 June 2015}} while maintaining that the content of the slides were meant for "academic discussion" only.{{cite news|title=No hard feelings, BTN boss tells ‘indie’ scene after attack slides leaked|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/no-hard-feelings-btn-boss-tells-indie-scene-after-attack-slides-leaked|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=The Malay Mail Online|date=16 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623145631/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/no-hard-feelings-btn-boss-tells-indie-scene-after-attack-slides-leaked|archivedate=23 June 2015}} Other slides published by the agency included a slide that examined the performance of the [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN) ruling coalition from 1959 to 2014 with racial breakdown of popular votes towards BN and [[Pakatan Rakyat]] (PR) seats and also percentages of Muslim and non-Muslim [[member of parliament]] (MPs) in [[Parliament of Malaysia]].{{cite web|title=Politik Malaysia|url=https://archive.org/details/POLITIKMALAYSIA|publisher=Biro Tata Negara|accessdate=23 June 2015}} Another slide had accused Chinese newspapers of being "fine needles that penetrate the government whilst promoting opposition movements." The national opposition party [[Democratic Action Party]] (DAP) is accused of using several Malay leaders to purportedly "destroy the Malay community". DAP was also accused in the slide of controlling the minds of people from [[Sabah]] and [[Sarawak]] by invoking the issue of [[Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop of Kuala Lumpur v Menteri Dalam Negeri|the use of the name "Allah" in the context of local Christian presses]], and inciting separation of both states from Malaysia.{{cite news|last1=Tan|first1=Tarrence|title=BTN is Apartheid 2.0 in M’sia, says DAP|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/16/btn-is-apartheid-2-0-in-msia-says-dap/|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=Free Malaysia Today|date=16 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618195549/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/16/btn-is-apartheid-2-0-in-msia-says-dap/|archivedate=18 June 2015}} The slide also claimed that a change in the current government will cause "political instability" in the country, bringing up comparisons with the [[Pol Pot]]'s [[Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia|Khmer Rouge regime]].{{cite web|title=Perkembangan Cabaran Politik semasa dalam negara (Development of current political challenges in the country)|url=https://archive.org/details/PERKEMBANGANCABARANPOLITIKSEMASADALAMNEGARA|publisher=Biro Tata Negara|accessdate=23 June 2015|language=Malay}} Another slide presents a breakdown of a list of the 10 richest men in Malaysia, where most of them are Chinese, and also the situation of Christians "being allowed to build large churches despite only accounting for 9.1% of the total population in Malaysia". It also argued that "racism can unite a nation or race", whereas the racial minorities in Malaysia "already have their needs fulfilled as entitled under [[international human rights law]]s".{{cite web|title=Rasis (Racist)|url=https://archive.org/details/RASIS|publisher=Biro Tata Negara|accessdate=23 June 2015}}{{cite news|title=BTN’s own slides proof of racism, says Kasturi|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/21/btns-own-slides-proof-of-racism-says-kasturi/|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=Free Malaysia Today|date=21 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623151745/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/21/btns-own-slides-proof-of-racism-says-kasturi/|archivedate=23 June 2015}} == Abolishment == In August 2018, [[Syed Saddiq Syed Abdul Rahman]], the Youth and Sports Minister of Malaysia announced that the National Civics Bureau will be abolished with immediate effect. {{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysias-national-service-programme-national-civics-bureau-abolished-says-youth-and|title=Malaysia's NS programme, National Civics Bureau abolished, says Youth and Sports Minister Syed Saddiq|last=hermesauto|date=2018-08-13|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.malaymail.com/s/1661883/syed-saddiq-btn-national-service-abolished|title=Syed Saddiq: BTN, National Service abolished {{!}} Malay Mail|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}} The decision to scrap the BTN programme was made during two successive Cabinet meetings, because evidence shown that the programme was misused to spread misguided indoctrination. The staff and resources under the National Civics Bureau programme will be reassigned to work in other ministries of the Malaysian government.{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/malaysia-abolishes-national-service-programme-civics-bureau-10612398|title=Malaysia abolishes national service programme, civics bureau|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en-US}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.btn.gov.my/}} {{Federal Government of Malaysia}} {{portal|Malaysia}} [[Category:Malaysian federal ministries, departments and agencies]] [[Category:Former Malaysian federal ministries, departments and agencies]] [[Category:Prime Minister's Department (Malaysia)]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Malaysia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1981]] [[Category:Active citizenship]] [[Category:Patriotic societies]] [[Category:Social science institutes]] [[Category:Youth organisations based in Malaysia]] [[Category:Government agencies disestablished in 2018]] [[Category:2018 disestablishments in Malaysia]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Nepal Medical Council |image = |size = |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = NMC |formation = 1964 Feb 28 |type = <!-- GO, NGO, IGO, INGO, etc --> |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = <!-- focus as e.g. humanitarian, peacekeeping, etc --> |headquarters = Kathmandu |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = <!-- position title for the leader of the org --> |leader_name = Prof. Dr. Dharma Kanta Baskota, Chairman |main_organ = Council |parent_organization = <!-- if one --> |affiliations = [[Government of Nepal]] |website = [http://www.nmc.org.np/ Official website] |remarks = }} The '''Nepal Medical Council''' (NMC) is a statutory body regulating [[medical education]] and registration of doctors in [[Nepal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmc.org.np|title=NMC|website=www.nmc.org.np}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Foreign doctors without NMC permission arrested|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/news/35294/?categoryId=81|publisher=MyRepublica|accessdate=27 Mar 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Entrance must for PG courses: NMC|url=https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/entrance-must-pg-courses-nmc/|publisher=TheHimalayanTimes|accessdate=27 Mar 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=NMC bars two Norvic doctors for 30 days|url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2018-03-08/nmc-bars-two-norvic-doctors-for-30-days.html|publisher=TheKathmanduPost|accessdate=27 Mar 2018}}</ref>
NMC was established in 1964 under Nepal Medical Council Act 1964. Chairman of NMC is nominated by Government of Nepal whereas Vice-Chairman is elected from NMC members. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmc.org.np/contents/history-information.html|title=NMC history information|website=www.nmc.org.np}}</ref>
NMC is one of many statutory bodies related to Healthcare in Nepal. Other are [[Nepal Nursing Council (NNC)]], Nepal Pharmacy Council, [[Nepal Ayurvedic Medical Council]], Nepal Health Professional Council, Nepal Health Research Council.
==See also== *[[Nepal Nursing Council (NNC)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Education in Nepal]]

revision.text:
The '''Osgood Center for International Studies''' is a not-for-profit educational foundation located at 1629 K Street, NW, Suite 300, [[Washington, D.C.]]. It is named in honor of Robert E. Osgood and his wife Gretchen.
Robert Osgood served for over twenty-five years on the faculty of the [[Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies]], a part of [[Johns Hopkins University]]. In addition to serving as Dean of SAIS, Osgood served on the [[United States National Security Council]] (1969-1970) and as a member of the [[US Department of State]] [[Policy Planning Staff (United States)|Policy Planning Staff]] (1983–85).
The Osgood Center specializes in providing structured learning opportunities, experiential study programs, and internships in the [[Washington, D.C.]] area for college and university students from around the world. Its regular programs provide individual internships, simulation games for groups of students, January semester classes, and a summer institute on foreign policy.
It has cooperative programs with the [[Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies]] and with [[Tokyo University]].
[[Shelton Williams]] is the President of the Osgood Center. Its board of directors include Ambassadors to NATO [[Robert E. Hunter]] of the [[RAND Corporation]] and Erin Mosley, Vice-President of [[Lockheed-Martin]].
==External links== *[http://www.osgoodcenter.org/ The Osgood Center Website]
[[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Internship programs]]

revision.text:
{{advert|date=January 2017}} {{refimprove|date=December 2017}} '''Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning''' ('''POGIL''') is a student-centered, group-learning instructional strategy and philosophy developed through research on how students learn best. POGIL was devised in 1994 to better teach general [[chemistry education|chemistry]]. Today, POGIL is implemented in a wide range of subjects in more than 1,000 American high schools and colleges.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.etsu.edu/news/2015/09_sep/patrickbrowntextbook.aspx|title=Professor authors Anatomy and Physiology textbook|author=Dr. Patrick Brown|work=News|publisher=East Tennessee State University|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref>
== Activities ==
There are two crucial aspects to the design of a POGIL activity. First, sufficient appropriate information must be provided for the initial "Exploration" so that students are able to develop the desired concepts. Second, the guiding questions must be sequenced in a carefully constructed manner so that not only do students reach the appropriate conclusion, but at the same time various process and learning skills are implemented and developed.
Typically the first few questions build on students' prior knowledge and direct attention to the information provided by the model. This is followed by questions designed to help promote the recognitions of relationships and patterns in the data, leading toward some concept development. The final questions may involve applying the concepts to new situations and generalizing students' new knowledge and understanding. Thus, POGIL activities follow the structure of the learning cycle of exploration, concept invention and application, and has a strong basis in constructivism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.physiology.org/doi/full/10.1152/advan.00104.2012|title=Process-oriented guided-inquiry learning improves long-term retention of information|author=Thea Vanags, Kristen Pammer, and Jay Brinker|date=20 July 2012|work=How We Teach|publisher=American Physiological Society|accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
== Classroom implementation ==
Students in a POGIL classroom may work in small groups of three or four to tackle a specifically designed activity. Each student is assigned a role, such as a task manager, recorder, spokesperson or reflector. The instructor acts as a facilitator who listens to the discussions between students, intervening at appropriate times to help facilitate student learning. In their groups, students may discuss and analyze problems and their answers to questions that are crafted to help lead them to consider the general ideas in question and to construct their own understanding of important concepts. As they formulate their ideas, they may share their understanding and discoveries with other groups.
Rather than having the instructor begin class by defining terms and laying out concepts, students work actively to master material and formulate a deeper understanding of content. Built into the experience is the support of a variety of important process skills, including communication, teamwork, and [[critical thinking]], which translates to a more complete understanding of the entire concept, and a lasting understanding of the material.
== The POGIL Project ==
The teaching method of POGIL is supported by the POGIL Project,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://serc.carleton.edu/sp/pkal/pogil/how.html|title=How to Use Process-Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning|work=Science Education Resource Center|publisher=Pedagogies of Engagement: Resource Collections|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> a [[non-profit]] [[501(c)3]] organization based in Lancaster, PA. The POGIL Project has earned numerous grants from the National Science Foundation and other sources. The POGIL Project is based on an understanding of the important components of an effective faculty development structure. The project trains faculty to implement POGIL in their classrooms, and creates new POGIL materials through an multitude of opportunities including [[workshops]], on-site visits, and consultancies. The project also hosts an annual POGIL National Meeting to grow and expand the POGIL community.
The current director of The POGIL Project is Rick Moog, a Professor of Chemistry at [[Franklin & Marshall College]]. Dr. Moog has used POGIL materials in his teaching since 1994, and is a co-author of POGIL materials for both general and [[physical chemistry]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.pogil.org The POGIL Project]
[[Category:Pedagogy]]

{{Multiple issues| {{+r|date=August 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = Scottish Science Advisory Council | bgcolor = <!-- header background color --> | fgcolor = <!-- header text color --> | image = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = SSAC | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and years ago|2002|05|07|df=y}} | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = [[Governmental organization|GO]] | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = Science advice and strategy for Scotland | headquarters = Room 1N:11, [[St Andrew's House]] | location = Regent Road, Edinburgh, EH1 3DG | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = Scotland | membership = Scottish scientists | language = <!-- official languages --> | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = Executive | leader_name = SSAC Secretariat | leader_title2 = Chairman | leader_name2 = [[Muffy Calder]], Chris Masters | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = [[Scottish Government]] | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|http://www.scottishscience.org.uk}} | remarks = | former name = }} The '''Scottish Science Advisory Council''' is a government organisation that is Scotland's highest level advisory body for science, engineering and technology.
The group of experts provide independent advice to the [[Scottish Government]]. Members are appointed by the [[Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning]]. It acts in an advisory role and does not direct any research funding, which comes from the [[UK Research Councils]].
==History== Scotland has a [[Scottish inventions and discoveries|proud tradition]] of science research and innovation, but this tends to be exclusively found in its main universities. R&D in Scottish industry is lower than the rest of the UK ([[Countries of the United Kingdom|RUK]]).<ref>[http://www.scottishscience.org.uk/sites/default/files/article-attachments/SSAC-Report-business-R%26D-in-Scotland-A-missing-link.pdf Report August 2009]</ref> Scotland has 10% of the population of the UK but produces 30% of the [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]s in microbiology and genetics. The [[University of Dundee]] is noted for its work in biochemistry.
However in physical sciences, from 1999–2004, there was a 12% drop in Scottish graduates, and a 17% drop in engineering and technology graduates. In the post-war years, and up to the early 1990s, Scotland was producing more than its fair share of science and engineering graduates; it was seen a popular and challenging option, although mainly among males. Now, proportionately more children at Scottish schools are perceived to be indifferent to the challenges that science presents. Older science teachers at Scottish schools are not being replaced in the number needed. ''Why Science Matters'', the 2003 report, found that Scotland was short of around 350 chemistry teachers and 200 physics teachers.
The organisation was announced in August 2001, and founded by the Royal Society of Edinburgh, with funding from the Scottish Executive.
From 1 January 2007, it moved to the Office of the Chief Scientific Adviser. Previously it had been at the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]].
==See also== * [[Scottish Science Trust]] * [[Chief Scientific Adviser for Scotland]] * [[Scottish Council for Development and Industry]] * [[Campaign for Science and Engineering]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.scottishscience.org.uk}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} The '''Sir Ninian Stephen Lecture''' is an annual public lecture held by the [[University of Newcastle, Australia|University of Newcastle]] Law School. The first lecture was delivered by former [[Governor-General of Australia]] Sir [[Ninian Stephen]] in 1993, to celebrate the establishment of the Bachelor of Laws program at the University. This event continues under his name, and is generally held in the early weeks of the academic year. The 2017 lecture was delivered on 11 August 2017 by Justice Margaret Beazley, President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal titled "Language, Law's Essential Tool."
== Sir Ninian Stephen Lecturers ==
* 1993 - Sir [[Ninian Stephen]], "Our Democratic Constitution" * 1994 - Justice [[Michael McHugh (judge)|Michael McHugh]], "The Growth of Legislation and Litigation" * 1995 - Justice [[Deirdre O'Connor]], "The Effect of Australia's International Obligations on the Development of Our System of Industrial Relations" * 1996 - Chief Justice [[Murray Gleeson]], "The Secrecy of Jury Deliberations" * 1997 - Justice [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]], "Constitutional Centenary and the Counting of Blessings" * 1998 - [[Gordon Samuels]], "No More Cabs on the Rank? Some Reflections about the Future of Legal Practice" * 1999 - Chief Justice [[James Spigelman]], "Statutory Interpretation: Identify the Linguistic Register" * 2000 - Sir [[Gerard Brennan]], "Principle and Independence: The Guardians of Freedom" * 2001 - [[Garth Nettheim]], "Making a Difference: Reconciling our Differences" * 2002 - [[Hilary Charlesworth]], "International Law and Australian Law in the 21st Century" * 2003 - [[Noel Pearson]], "The High Court's Abandonment of the 'Time Honoured Methodology of the Common Law' in its Interpretation of Native Title in ''Mirriuwung Gajerrong'' and ''Yorta Yorta''" * 2004 - [[Julian Burnside]], "The Practice of Law: Justice or Just a Job" * 2005 - [[Margaret Cunneen]], "Living Within the Law" * 2006 - [[Frank Brennan (Jesuit)|Frank Brennan]], "Confessions of an Erstwhile Land Rights Advocate" * 2007 - [[Graeme Innes]], "Using the Law to Make a Difference" * 2008 - Justice [[John Basten]], "Human Rights and the Rule of Law" * 2009 - [[Stephen Gageler]], "Fact and Law" * 2010 - [[Hal Wootten]], "Finding a Life in the Law" * 2011 - Justice [[Julie Ward (judge)|Julie Ward]], "The Modern Day Fusion Falacy - Should There Be a Separate Bar?" * 2012 - [[Kevin Lindgren]], "The Rule of Law: Its State of Health in Australia" * 2013 - [[Nicola Roxon]], "Breathing value into your law degree" * 2014 - Chief Justice [[Robert French]], "The Practising of Law in a Global Neighbourhood" * 2015 - Professor [[Neil Rees]], "I look ahead" * 2016 - Justice [[Virginia Bell]], "Equality, Proportionality and Dignity : The Guiding Principles for a Just Legal System" * 2017 - Justice [[Margaret Beazley]], "Language: Law's Essential Tool"
==External links== * [http://www.newcastle.edu.au/school/law/about/ninian-stephen.html University of Newcastle – Sir Ninian Stephen Lecture]
[[Category:Lecture series|Stephen]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox_University |image = |name = Tashkent State University of Law |established = 2013 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |rector = Prof. Esemurat Kanyazov Sultamuratovich |city = [[Tashkent]] |country = [[Uzbekistan]] |students = 2,100 |staff = 192 |website = [http://www.tsul.uz TSUL] }} '''Tashkent State University of Law''' ('''TSUL''') is a public [[law school]] in [[Tashkent]], [[Uzbekistan]].
Tashkent State University of Law (TSUL) is a state university which provides legal education in the Republic of Uzbekistan. It also holds a status of the main research institution in the sphere of law. TSUL was established in accordance with the Decree of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan dated on 28th of June 2013. TSUL is the first University in the Republic of Uzbekistan which started to deliver education based on module system. TSUL delivers both bachelor and masters programs. Bachelor program lasts for 4 years and masters 1 years. There are five bachelor programs namely: public law and governance; private law; business law; criminal law; international law. Master of law programs are: '''5A240108''' - public law and governance; '''5A240109''' - labor law; '''5A240116''' - applying theory and practice of criminal law; '''5A240118''' - law and busines; '''5A240119''' - law and information technologies; '''5A240120''' - financial-legal monitoring.
TSUL also delivers a postgraduate program (PhD). The postgraduate students are employed by TSUL as senior research fellows.
==Academics== TSUL has 19 departments where 13 departments are specialised in various areas of law. Academic staff of TSUL is around of 192 people. A number of staff holds PhD degree in law and LLM degrees obtained from the Universities of US and UK, Japan. 14 modules are taught in English.
The TSUL offers two degrees.
* '''Bachelor of Law''' is the basic degree offered by the TSUL. Students can choose a number of specializations and follow a course of four years to get their degree. With the completion of the state exams, graduates acquire a diploma that is a professional qualification. * '''Master of Laws''' is a one-year graduate degree in which law graduates can specialize in such programs as public law and governance; labor law; applying theory and practice of criminal law; law and busines; law and information technologies; financial-legal monitoring.
Tashkent State University of Law provides full-time undergraduate, full-time graduate, and part-time postgraduate programs.
==Campus==
The campus of TSUL is in downtown Tashkent close to government buildings and the courts. Its central location gives graduates and professors extraordinary access to government offices and the offices of international non-governmental organizations.
==Alumni==
TSUL boasts the most prestigious alumni in Uzbekistan with several present and former ministers who are graduates, the majority of the judiciary, and many prominent statesmen.
==External links==
*[http://www.tsul.uz Tashkent State University of Law Website] *[http://www.tsul.uz/forum Tashkent State Institute of Law Forum]
{{coord missing|Uzbekistan}}
[[Category:Uzbekistani law]] [[Category:Law schools in Uzbekistan]] [[Category:Education in Tashkent|State University of Law]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tashkent|State University of Law]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Teen Turn | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | type = | founded = 2016 | founders = Joanne Dolan and Niambh Scullion | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = [[Ireland]] | industry = Technology | products = | website = [https://teen-turn.com/ teenturn.com] }}
'''Teen Turn''' is an [[Ireland|Irish]] [[Charity (practice)|charity]] which encourages teenage girls aged to pursue careers in [[technology]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Initiative aims to get teenage girls into tech |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/technology/2017/0811/896795-teen-turn/ |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=11 August 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
==History== Teen Turn is an Irish charity which was founded in 2016 by Joanne Dolan and Niambh Scullion with the aim of promoting technology and [[Computer literacy|computer skills]] to girls in disadvantaged areas. It was first trialed in the summer of 2016 with 20 girls from five schools, and since has expanded to 18 schools and 30 tech companies.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gorey |first1=Colm |title=Teen-Turn girls’ work experience programme to go international in 2018 |url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/careers/teen-turn-girls-work-experience |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=Silicon Republic |date=31 July 2017}}</ref>
==Activities== In particular the group aim to work with girls from communities with low uptake of university or third level education. They partner with technology and digital companies to provide work placements and mentoring.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Short |first1=Eva |title=‘ACIA really wanted to be part of the Teen-Turn experience’ |url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/people/acia-aon-teen-turn |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=Silicon Republic |date=20 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Reporter |first1=Post |title=Leading for change: bringing gender equality to the fore {{!}} BusinessPost.ie |url=https://www.businesspost.ie/focus-on/leading-change-bringing-gender-equality-fore-429683 |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=www.businesspost.ie |date=4 November 2018}}</ref> They provide two week work placements.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/jobs/teen-turn-programme-stem-internships|title=Teen-Turn programme to combat gender stereotypes in STEM|last=Gorey|first=Colm|date=2016-04-18|work=Silicon Republic|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-GB}}</ref> The charity also run after school programs. Participants from this program in Limerick went on to win the BT Young Pioneer Award in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://irishtechnews.ie/2018-finalists-for-bt-young-pioneer-award-include-limerick-teen-girls-who-created-a-mental-health-tracker-app/|title=2018 Finalists for BT Young Pioneer Award include Limerick teen girls who created a mental health tracker app. – Irish Tech News|last=O Donnabhain|first=Cal|date=18 June 2018|website=irishtechnews.ie|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> In 2018, Teen Turn partnered with [[The Digital Hub]] and [[Gaisce – The President's Award|Gaisce]] to take part in the Technovation Challenge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedigitalhub.com/projects/the-digital-hub-to-host-technovation-challenge-2018-in-partnership-with-teen-turn/|title=The Digital Hub to host Technovation Challenge 2018|work=The Digital Hub|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Awards ===
* 2017 EU Digital Impact Organisation of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digitalimpactaward.com/2017-european-ada-award-finalists-named/|title=2017 European Ada Award Finalists Named – Digital Impact Award|website=digitalimpactaward.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/innovation/digital-girl-europe-2017-ada|title=Irish contestants scoop European Digital Girl of the Year prizes|last=Tannam|first=Ellen|date=2017-12-01|work=Silicon Republic|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://twitter.com/teenturn?lang=en Official Twitter account]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Joan Theresa Garrity''' (born c. 1940), is an American author, best known as the author of ''[[The Sensuous Woman]]''.
She was raised in [[Lee's Summit, Missouri]]<ref>[http://www.kclibrary.org/localhistory/media.cfm?mediaID=110633 Kansas City, MO Library bio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310210615/http://www.kclibrary.org/localhistory/media.cfm?mediaID=110633 |date=March 10, 2007 }}</ref> and she studied at [[Palm Beach Junior College]] in Florida. She worked on the staff of publisher [[Lyle Stuart]] and published a book about shopping in New York.
In 1969 she published, under the pseudonym of "J.", ''The Sensuous Woman'', subtitled "the first how-to book for the female who yearns to be all woman". It was also published as ''The Way to Become the Sensuous Woman''. The book spent eight weeks at No. 1 on the ''New York Times'' bestseller list and nearly a year on the list overall.<ref>John Bear, ''The No. 1 New York Times Best Seller: intriguing facts about the 484 books that have been #1 New York Times bestsellers since the first list, 50 years ago'', Berkeley: Ten Speed Press, 1992</ref> In later editions, she used the name Terry Garrity. A spoken-word record album was made in 1969, based on the book, called ''J – The Way To Become A Sensuous Woman''.<ref>Voxpop, [http://www.voxpopmusic.com/ViewProdDetails.asp?prod_code=11676&Prod_name=The+Way+To+Become+A+Sensuous+Woman&CAT_CODE=15&SUBCAT_CODE=36 "J – The Way To Become A Sensuous Woman" (LP)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311141307/http://www.voxpopmusic.com/ViewProdDetails.asp?prod_code=11676&Prod_name=The+Way+To+Become+A+Sensuous+Woman&CAT_CODE=15&SUBCAT_CODE=36 |date=March 11, 2007 }}</ref><ref>Hyp Records, [http://www.hipwax.com/music/oddpop/sex_ed.html "The Amorous Arts"]</ref>
In 1977, she published ''Total Loving: how to love and be loved for the rest of your life'', and in 1984, ''Story of "J": the author of The Sensuous Woman tells the bitter price of her crazy success'', with her brother John Garrity as co-author. In this book she and her brother discuss how she coped with [[bipolar disorder]].<ref>John Garrity, [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/features/1998/weekly/980907/teeingoff.html "Teeing Off: The Wrong Diagnosis?] Sports Illustrated/CNN, September 2, 1998</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Bill Althaus, "Putting 'J' behind Her: For Terry Garrity, Success Was Almost Fatal", ''Kansas City Magazine'', October 1984
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Teshome Gabriel|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Teshome H. Gabriel''' (September 24, 1939 – June 14, 2010) was an [[Ethiopia]]n-born [[United States|American]] cinema scholar and professor at the [[UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television]] in Los Angeles. Gabriel was considered an expert on cinema and film of Africa and the [[developing world]].<ref name=latimes> {{cite news |first=Dennis|last=McClellan|title=Teshome H. Gabriel dies at 70; UCLA professor and Third World cinema expert|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-teshome-gabriel-20100617,0,28810.story|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=|date=2010-06-17 |accessdate=2010-07-03}}</ref> A colleague at UCLA, [[Vinay Lal]], noted that Gabriel was "one of the first scholars to theorize in a critical fashion about [[Third World]] cinema."<ref name=latimes/>
Gabriel was born in Ticho, [[Ethiopia]], on September 24, 1939.<ref name=latimes/> He immigrated to the United States in 1962.<ref name=latimes/> He obtained a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[political science]] in 1967 and received a [[master's degree]] in educational media in 1969, both from the [[University of Utah]].<ref name=latimes/> He continued his education at [[UCLA]], where he earned a master's degree in [[theater arts]] in 1976 and a [[doctorate]] in [[film studies|film]] and [[television studies]] in 1979.<ref name=latimes/>
Gabriel began lecturing at UCLA in 1974 and became an assistant professor at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television in 1981.<ref name=latimes/>
Gabriel's books included ''Third Cinema in the Third World: The Aesthetics of Liberation'' in 1982 and ''Third Cinema: Exploration of Nomadic Aesthetics & Narrative Communities''.<ref name=latimes/> He co-edited ''Otherness and the Media: The Ethnography of the Imagined and the Imaged'', which was published in 1993.<ref name=latimes/> He served as the [[editor]] of ''Emergences: Journal for the Study of Media and Composite Cultures''.<ref name=latimes/> Additionally, Gabriel founded ''Tuwaf'' (''Light''), an Ethiopian journal on [[fine arts]] which is published in [[Amharic]]. He served on ''Tuwaf's'' editorial board from 1987 until 1991.<ref name=latimes/>
Teshome Gabriel died of cardiac arrest on June 14, 2010, at Kaiser Permanente Panorama City Medical Center in [[Panorama City, Los Angeles]] at the age of 70.<ref name=latimes/> He was survived by his wife, Maaza Woldemusie; daughter, Mediget; and son, Tsegaye.<ref name=latimes/>
http://teshomegabriel.net/ is a website with many of his academic articles.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gabriel, Teshome}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Ethiopian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Film educators]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:UCLA Film School alumni]] [[Category:University of Utah alumni]] [[Category:American people of Ethiopian descent]]

revision.text:
{{About|the group of French academics}}
'''The Cooperative''' was an informal group of famous French academics organized in 1907 to teach their children at a higher level than was available in Paris at the time. The group started when [[Marie Curie|Marie]] and [[Pierre Curie]] noticed the strong mathematical potential of their daughter, [[Irène Joliot-Curie|Irène]]. Unable to find a school that could meet her needs, they joined forces with several other parents with strong academic backgrounds including [[Paul Langevin]] and [[Jean Perrin]], and decided to take turns teaching one another's children.
The curriculum of The Cooperative was varied and included not only the principles of science and scientific research but such diverse subjects as Chinese and sculpture, with great emphasis placed on self-expression and play.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.woodrow.org/teachers/ci/1992/IreneJoliot-Curie.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714121032/http://www.woodrow.org/teachers/ci/1992/IreneJoliot-Curie.html |archivedate=2007-07-14 |df= }} Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation</ref>
== Notable results == Irène Curie won the Nobel prize for chemistry in 1935.
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cooperative}} [[Category:French academics]] [[Category:Homeschooling]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1907]] [[Category:1907 establishments in France]]

page.title: The Duke of Edinburgh's Hillary Award

revision.comment: Fixed my coding typo. Reminder to self - use that 'show preview' button!
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2017}}
'''The Duke of Edinburgh's Hillary Award''', also known as '''The Duke of Edinburgh's Award''', is a [[New Zealand]] award modelled on [[The Duke of Edinburgh's Award]]. The name of the award is a reference to the famous New Zealand [[mountaineer]] [[Edmund Hillary|Sir Edmund Hillary]].
==Overview== The Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award is a voluntary, non-competitive programme of practical, cultural and adventurous activities, designed to support the personal and social development of young people aged 14–25, regardless of gender, background or ability. It offers an individual challenge and encourages young people to undertake exciting, constructive, challenging and enjoyable activities in their free time.
The mission of The Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award Programme in New Zealand is to have young people, regardless of cultural, ethnic and socio-economic background, participating in an exciting, flexible and individually tailored programme, to build skills, identity and self-esteem.<ref>{{cite web|title=What it’s all about|url=http://www.dofehillary.org.nz/Site/about_the_award/default.aspx}}</ref>
Approximately 9000 young New Zealanders' undertake the award every year.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Zealand’s Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award programme reaches international heights|url=http://www.myd.govt.nz/news/2014/duke-of-edinburghs-hillary-award-programme-reaches-international-heights.html}}</ref>
==History== The constitution of the Award in New Zealand was drawn up on 19 July 1963 during the inaugural meeting of the National Council of The Duke of Edinburgh's Award in New Zealand held at [[Government House, Wellington]].<ref name=history>{{cite web|title=History of the Award|url=http://www.dofehillary.org.nz/Site/about_the_award/History.aspx|website=The Duke of Edinburgh's Hillary Award|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref>
The award was renamed from ''The Duke of Edinburgh's Award'' to ''Duke of Edinburgh's Hillary Award'' in 2009 following the death of [[Edmund Hillary|Sir Edmund Hillary]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Speech to the Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award 50th anniversary dinner, Government House Wellington|url=https://gg.govt.nz/content/duke-edinburgh%E2%80%99s-hillary-award-50th-anniversary-dinner}}</ref> It has also been known as ''The Young New Zealanders Challenge of the Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award''.<ref name=history />
==See also== *[[The Duke of Edinburgh's Award]] ([[DofE]])
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.dofehillary.org.nz/ Official site]

page.title: United Nations Asian and Pacific Training Centre for Information and Communication Technology for Development

/* External links */
revision.text:
The WAC Clearinghouse publishes [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]], [[Open access|open-access]] journals and books, as well as other professional resources for teachers and instructional materials for students. [[Writing across the curriculum|Writing-across-the-curriculum]] (WAC) refers to a formal programmatic approach within contemporary secondary and higher education composition studies that promotes the importance of writing in classes outside of composition.
Working in partnership with the Association for Writing Across the Curriculum Programs (AWAC), the WAC Clearinghouse operates as a publishing collaborative, drawing on contributions from more than 125 individuals serving on the editorial boards of [[Academic journal|academic journals]] supported by the Clearinghouse, as editors or reviewers of its book series, as editors of resource pages on its website, and as members of the overall Clearinghouse editorial board. The open-access character of the scholarship available through the Clearinghouse book series provides free access to scholarly books and [[Textbook|textbooks]], providing students and teachers with an alternative to purchasing scholarly and classroom instructional materials. For individuals and libraries who wish to own print copies of its books, the Clearinghouse works with [[University Press of Colorado|University Press of Colorado]] to make print books available in low-cost editions. The Clearinghouse also collaborates with other open-access publishers in the field of [[Composition_studies|writing studies]], including Computers and Composition [[Digital printing|Digital Press]] and Writing Spaces, which both publish open-access scholarly work, including innovative, [[Multimodality|multimodal]] digital writing projects, using traditional academic peer reviewed processes. The WAC Clearinghouse addresses several disciplinary areas within writing studies, such as [[Second language writing|second-language writing]], [[Writing fellow|writing fellows]], and writing in the [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] disciplines.
==History== Established in 1997,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wac.colostate.edu/about/brief-history/|title=A Brief History of the WAC Clearinghouse|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref> the Clearinghouse is among the most successful open-access publishing projects in the humanities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bazerman|first1=Charles|title=Open access book publishing in writing studies: A case study|journal=First Monday|date=7 January 2008|volume=13|issue=1|url=http://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/2088/1920}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Palmquist|first1=Mike|last2=Mullin|first2=Joan|last3=Blalock|first3=Glenn|editor=Lee Nickoson|others=Mary P. Sheridan|title=Writing Studies Research in Practice: Methods and Methodologies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q5bQn1AyDH0C&pg=PA234|accessdate=21 May 2016|year=2012|publisher=SIU Press|isbn=9780809331154|pages=231–245|chapter=The Role of Activity Analysis in Writing Research: Case Studies of Emerging Scholarly Communities}}</ref> It supports eight academic journals, including ''The WAC Journal,'' focused on WAC theory and ideas; ''Across the Disciplines,'' devoted to language, learning and academic writing; ''Double Helix,'' an international journal on writing, critical thinking, pedagogical theory and classroom practice; and ''RhetNet,'' an online journal of rhetoric and composition that explores what "net" publishing may be in its natural form, as well as several others. The Clearinghouse also has published 90 books<ref>{{cite book|last1=Neff|first1=Joyce Magnotto|last2=Whithaus|first2=Carl|title=Writing Across Distances and Disciplines: Research and Pedagogy in Distributed Learning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9f-OAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT239|year=2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135596767|page=239}}</ref> and provides access to peer-reviewed resources for teachers who wish to use writing in courses across the disciplines, including a bibliography (published in collaboration with CompPile, which became part of the Clearinghouse in 2018), resource pages on writing fellows programs and [[Second language|second-language]] learners, conference proceedings, WAC program descriptions, a list of scholarly journals, and the 2014 Statement on WAC Principles and Practices, among others.
==Sustainable Publishing Initiative==
In May 2012, to mark its fifteenth year of operation, the WAC Clearinghouse launched the 25 Collective, a demonstration project for sustainable publishing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wac.colostate.edu/sustain/|title=The Sustainable Publishing Initiative|accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref> The goal of the project was to publish 25 new books for a total expenditure of $50,000—a cost far below that borne by traditional academic presses. Leveraging university resources (office space, computing resources, and web servers), the project operated within its budget and had, by March 2017, reached its goal, producing 29 books at an average cost of less than $2000 per book. The success of the project led to the launch of the Colorado State University Open Press<ref>{{cite web|url=https://press.colostate.edu/|title=Colorado State University Open Press|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref>, a publishing project that supports the use of the publishing collaborative model developed through the WAC Clearinghouse in other disciplines.
==Support==
The Clearinghouse is hosted by [[Colorado State University]] and receives support from the Colorado State University Open Press. It also receives support from donations and funds from purchases of selected books in print form. Donations are used to defray costs associated with honoraria for graduate students who serve as copy editors and designers for Clearinghouse books, for accessibility to the Web site and publications, for the purchase of [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN numbers]], and for software and equipment expense. Interested patrons my donate online or by check through the Clearinghouse Web site.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *WAC Clearinghouse {{official website|https://wac.colostate.edu}} *[https://wac.colostate.edu/awac/ Association for Writing Across the Curriculum Programs (AWAC)] *[https://press.colostate.edu/ Colorado State University Open Press] *[http://ccdigitalpress.org/ Computers and Composition Digital Press] *[http://writingspaces.org/ Writing Spaces Open Textbook Project] *[https://wac.colostate.edu/principles/ 2014 Statement on WAC Principles and Practices,] *[https://upcolorado.com/ University Press of Colorado]
